commit_message:
Support Keystone versionless endpoints

Uses keystone.client instead of keystone.client.v3 with session and auth
to return a keystone client with the discovered URL.

Also sets project_domain_name and user_domain_name do "Default" as they
are expected by Keystone.

Change-Id: I8fce922e2907584138a132f37887f227eabe9abe
Partial-Bug: #1688320

commit_message:
Update eventlet uc to 0.21.0

Eventlet has released v0.21.0 and fix following bugs:
- Allow services use TLS-enabled mysql connection over monkey-patch. [1]
- Bringback option EVENTLET_NO_GREENDNS that affected nova, designate.. [2]

[1]. https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/commit/8e92d15d266b78720d4cc780cd2878377dcf7775
[2]. https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/issues/390

Depends-On: I48179953ef19ec6b2f3f6706337a1dae1b3830bd
Change-Id: I3c56ee5cdcb62ed85c3dfe9150b18a02ec9f8d93

There are a number of Pep8 checks that fail when testing using
Python3.  This commit corrects those issues:

- For test cases using the 'file' built-in a '# noqa' was added
- Add '# noqa' for cases where the 'buffer' built-in was used
- Use of 'unicode' was switched to 'six.text_type'

Also, somehow a whole file with Windows newline characters was merged.

(cherry picked from commit 9517dd2592a9ee371540cd51a1001ddcf6bcc876)

commit_message:
Fix Pep8 Failures for Python3

There are a number of Pep8 checks that fail when testing using
Python3.  This commit corrects those issues:

- For test cases using the 'file' built-in a '# noqa' was added
- Add '# noqa' for cases where the 'buffer' built-in was used
- Use of 'unicode' was switched to 'six.text_type'

Also, somehow a whole file with Windows newline characters was merged.
This patch also fixes that problem.

Change-Id: I98cc7d1d42cd897d866c6190adf4121dc1cc30c0
(cherry picked from commit 9517dd2592a9ee371540cd51a1001ddcf6bcc876)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/82/463682/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Adding testcases for glance metadata def properties

This commit contains testcases for
      - add_metadata_def_namespace_properties
      - get_metadata_def_namespace_properties

Change-Id: Ic10f6967dc11424f447e74e3ed2aedba90c8a6b2
Partial-bug: #1606533
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/15/370315/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2016 Ericsson India Global Services Ltd Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest.api.image import base from tempest.common.utils import data_utils from tempest.lib.common.utils import test_utils from tempest.lib import exceptions as lib_exc from tempest import test class MetadataNamespacesPropertiesTest(base.BaseV2ImageTest): """Test the Metadata definition Namespaces properties functionality""" @test.idempotent_id('319b765e-7f3d-4b3d-8b37-3ca3876ee768') def test_basic_metadata_definition_namespaces(self): # get the available resource types and use one resource_type body = self.resource_types_client.list_resource_types() resource_name = body['resource_types'][0]['name'] name = [{'name': resource_name}] namespace_name = data_utils.rand_name('namespace') # create the metadef namespace body = self.namespaces_client.create_namespace( namespace=namespace_name, visibility='public', description='Tempest', display_name=namespace_name, resource_type_associations=name, protected=True) self.addCleanup(test_utils.call_and_ignore_notfound_exc, self._cleanup_namespace, namespace_name) # get namespace details body = self.namespaces_client.show_namespace(namespace_name) self.assertEqual(namespace_name, body['namespace']) self.assertEqual('public', body['visibility']) # unable to delete protected namespace self.assertRaises(lib_exc.Forbidden, self.namespaces_client.delete_namespace, namespace_name) # update the visibility to private and protected to False body = self.namespaces_client.update_namespace( namespace=namespace_name, description='Tempest', visibility='private', display_name=namespace_name, protected=False) self.assertEqual('private', body['visibility']) self.assertEqual(False, body['protected']) # now able to delete the non-protected namespace self.namespaces_client.delete_namespace(namespace_name) def _cleanup_namespace(self, namespace_name): body = self.namespaces_client.show_namespace(namespace_name) self.assertEqual(namespace_name, body['namespace']) body = self.namespaces_client.update_namespace( namespace=namespace_name, description='Tempest', visibility='private', display_name=namespace_name, protected=False) self.namespaces_client.delete_namespace(namespace_name) def test_add_namespace_metadef_properties(self): """ adding namespace metadef properties """ body = self.resource_types_client.list_resource_types() resource_name = body['resource_types'][0]['name'] name = [{'name': resource_name}] namespace_name = data_utils.rand_name('namespace') # create the metadef namespace body = self.namespaces_client.create_namespace( namespace=namespace_name, visibility='public', description='Tempest', display_name=namespace_name, resource_type_associations=name, protected=False) # invoking the namespace_properties_ property_name = data_utils.rand_name('test-ns-property') body = self.namespaces_client.add_md_namespace_properties( namespace_name, property_name) self.assertEqual(property_name, body['name']) resp, body_prop = self.namespaces_client.get_md_namespace_properties( namespace_name) self.assertEqual(property_name, body_prop['name']) # now able to delete the non-protected namespace self.namespaces_client.delete_namespace(namespace_name)

commit_message:
nova-manage: Deprecate 'agent' commands

These operations can be accomplished using the REST API [1]. There's no
reason to keep them in nova-manage.

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#guest-agents-os-agents

Change-Id: I5ab7f4a0847687e426fa28bc7a032684b931532f

commit_message:
Improve strings for translation

Rework HTML and Javascript to provide better strings for the translators
to work on. The existing code generated strings that contained unnecessary
HTML markup.

Change-Id: Ib528c64234d88c39b266e03a702f1ce50a96684f

commit_message:
logging message identifiers

Operators have been asking for mnemonic identifiers for log messages
tied to errors since the start of the Folsom cycle in 2012. Let's see
if we can finally deliver them.

Change-Id: If80b91ef0e853690587536abe975e7d6f3e9b891
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-specs refs/changes/10/460110/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============================= Logging Message Identifiers ============================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo.log/+spec/logging-message-ids Operators have been asking for mnemonic identifiers for log messages tied to errors since the start of the Folsom cycle in 2012. Let's see if we can finally deliver them. Problem description =================== Many commercial (closed-source) enterprise applications, and even some open source projects, include unique identifiers for every user and log message. The IDs are used as reference points in documentation and bug reports, either instead of or in addition to the text of the log message. Message IDs also mean that online searches can be language independent, to some degree, although translating the results of a search may still require someone to be able to read English if there are no results in their primary language. As an open source project with a widely distributed contributor base and multi-service architecture, adding message IDs to OpenStack presents some unique challenges not faced in other environments. A central repository of unique IDs will be difficult to maintain. Adding IDs to every log message in anticipation of documentation to be written later will produce a lot of patches with little value, triggering reviews, test jobs, and rebases of other patches. Requiring IDs for each log call, or for only some log levels, will require incompatible changes to our logging library APIs. This proposal tries to address all of those issues in a way that will allow us to see a beneficial outcome in the near term, while also encouraging incremental improvement in the longer term. Proposed change =============== .. note:: This proposal only applies to services using oslo.log for managing their logging setup. Although unique message IDs are useful, maintaining the list would grow tedious. Not every message needs extra documentation, and many messages are related because they appear under related conditions. Therefore, we will use "situation ID" values instead of "message ID" values. While a situation ID might be used only for one message, it can be applied to a set of related messages if that makes it more convenient to maintain the documentation. Situation IDs will be tied directly to URLs for documentation. A new Sphinx-based documentation set, the "Troubleshooting Guide", will be created under the "troubleshooting" directory in each repository with a deliverable supporting situation IDs. These new guides will be published to docs.openstack.org/troubleshooting/$PRODUCT_NAME, where PRODUCT_NAME is the value passed to log.setup() when oslo.log is initialized. This structure allows a situation ID to be used to build a URL for understanding that situation, such as docs.openstack.org/troubleshooting/cinder/123456.html The documentation for a situation ID should include the ID value, any variations of the log message (for example, if it changes over time), and details about what the message means. It may also include basic instructions for mitigating the problem (without going into too much detail), work-arounds, etc. This documentation should enhance well-written and useful log messages, rather than replace them. Operators should still be able to understand what OpenStack is doing by reading the logs, without the troubleshooting guides. Each situation ID is a combination of the project name and a 6 digit number (000000-999999). Because the IDs are tied to documentation in a git repository, all of the services delivered from that repository should use IDs allocated from the same range (i.e., all of the services in the openstack/nova repository will come from the same range and cannot overlap, but the openstack/ceilometer and openstack/aodh repositories will each have their own troubleshooting guide and so each can use the full range of allowed ID values). Support for optional situation IDs will be added to oslo.log. If a ``situation_id`` value appears in the extras associated with a logging call, it will be placed at the end of the log message, in square brackets, with the product name prepended (e.g., "``some message [cinder-123456]``"). If no situation ID is passed to the logging call, the situation ID field will be left off entirely. This placement allows logging parsers to be updated to look for the optional IDs, without breaking the existing parsing. In other cases where we have "standard" but optional parts of messages, we replace missing values with "-". For situation IDs, we won't do this because every single log line would end with "[-]", which adds to the log volume without adding useful information. For operators who want control of where the ID appears in the log line, we will watch for ``%(situation_id)s`` to appear in the format string. If it is present, it will be filled in with the situation ID or "[-]" if there is no ID. Adding this as an optional parameter means that operators who want to always have the value can configure their systems that way, but our default configuration does not change in a backwards-incompatible way. Situation IDs should not be added to the request context, because almost no situation has such a global scope. Situation IDs are allocated when someone (ideally an operator) contributes documentation for the situation. This gives the developers an opportunity to review the documentation for correctness, as well as to understand the sort of information that is useful to operators for troubleshooting. IDs should only be added to logging calls with the accompanying documentation (together, in one patch). A hacking validator will be written to make it easy to ensure this policy is followed without requiring reviewer attention. The patch to add the situation documentation should also update all of the related logging calls to pass the situation_id. Because the IDs come from filenames, we can use merge conflicts to help us catch cases of reusing the same ID incorrectly. Once allocated, a situation ID is not changed. If the text of a log message associated with a situation ID changes, the documentation for that ID should be updated to include the old and the new text of the message, with information about which release series use which version of the text. Within a repository, the number range can be segmented based on service name, functional area, etc. The details of that segmentation are left up to each project team to decide and document in the contributor instructions for the team. Project teams are encouraged to use simple segmenting rules, or to write custom hacking rules, to make reviews easier. Situation IDs will be scoped *only* to log messages. API error responses and exceptions will not be changed as part of this proposal. If the IDs for logging prove useful, we can consider how to extend them to the other cases in the future. Log formatters and handlers that allow separate fields, such as the JSONFormatter and OSJournalHandler, should be extended to emit the message ID in those fields instead of adding it to the message text. Open Questions -------------- 1. How do we handle IDs in libraries, which do not call oslo.log's setup() function? Include the name prefix in the ID when it is added to the call? Make oslo.log derive the name portion of the ID based on where the log call is made? 2. We may not want to start publishing a given troubleshooting guide until there is a critical mass of useful information written for it. How do we decide when to start publishing? When should new troubleshooting guides be added to the list of published guides? Alternatives ------------ 1. The first public specification related to this topic was posted in glance-specs under the title "Glance Error Codes": https://review.openstack.org/#/c/127482 The Glance spec was eventually moved to the cross-project specs repo with the title "OpenStack wide Error Codes for Log Messages": https://review.openstack.org/#/c/172552 Both of those proposals suffered from an over emphasis on details that invited bike shedding, while ignoring implementation details that actually blocked adoption of the specs. This proposal is an attempt to invert that situation. 2. We could, once and for all, declare that this is not a feature we are going to add to OpenStack. 3. We could adopt this proposal, but include a unique ID for every message instead of collecting related messages together with the same ID. Validating the uniqueness across logging calls would be a bit more complex, but could be done. It's not clear that it's worth the effort. 4. We could place the message documentation in a centralized guide, instead of placing each section in the same repository as the application to which it refers. Setting message IDs in the central guide would make validation more complex, since the validator would need to refer to a resource outside of the repository under test when the ID is added to the logging call(s). Having a central guide would also complicate maintenance and discussions about who has review rights, which projects can add information, etc. We have been moving to decentralize documentation of this sort, and adding a new central document would reverse that trend. 5. We could place the troubleshooting guide for an application, or set of applications, in its own repository. This solves the ownership question, but has the same validation-related drawbacks as creating a centralized guide. comment 6. We could place the situation ID at the start of the logging output and replace missing ID values with "-", as we do for other key message components. However, this would alter the logging format in a way that is not backwards compatible with existing log parsers. Operators who want the value to be at the start of the format string can always add it there using their local configuration. 7. We could have oslo.log emit the URL pointing to the documentation for the situation ID instead of or in addition to the situation ID itself (it will have enough information to do this). This is left for a future enhancement, when we have enough situation IDs documented to make it useful. 8. We could use hexadecimal instead of decimal codes to extend the ranges. Starting with decimal allows us to extend the range later if we need to go beyond 1,000,000 codes for any given application. 9. We could use English language mnemonics instead of numerical values. Choosing a specific language does not help operators for whom language is the primary barrier to understanding the existing log messages. 10. We could use more complex message IDs, encoding things like the component, driver, etc. This is not necessary with our logging tools, because we can have each log line include the module name and line number where the message is produced. Project teams are free to segment the ID space for their projects in the ways they think most useful, although more complicated segmentation rules will result in more complicated reviewer rules. 11. We could use UUIDs for message IDs. They could either be completely random UUID4, or UUID5 values with a project-specific seed to ensure separation. UUIDs ensure uniqueness, and we have a well established pattern of using UUIDs as unique identifiers throughout OpenStack. Using them for message IDs would require the contributor to run a tool to produce the value, which makes it slightly more difficult to add a message ID. UUIDs are also harder to remember and relay in non-text mediums, which may make them less useful as mnemonics. 12. The Fault Genes team has a tool to scrape code for exceptions and build a searchable database of error messages from it. http://172.99.106.155/exceptions/#/ We could support this more fully by tweaking our exception definitions to make them easier to scrape. Doing so would mean very few, if any, changes would need to be made to application code and no new Troubleshooting Guide documentation set support would be needed. It would also address the complaint many operators have about the difficulty of landing patches, because improvements to the documentation for a message would be included in the Fault Genes project instead of other projects. 13. We could write something to scrape exception definitions and publish the results using static Troubleshooting Guides. This would keep the docs close to the code, and would allow us to ensure that all exceptions have good docstrings. The most likely solution for this alternative is to create a sphinx extension, because that would allow us to interleave documentation extracted from the source code with hand-written information. Given the number of exception classes, attaching some additional information to the exception class will make sense in the long run, although it doesn't address the standalone logging messages. 14. We could call "situation IDs" "message IDs" instead. The alternate name was proposed because the values are not unique to the message, but if it causes confusion that distinction may not be worth making. References ------------- * `Lessons learned from working on large scale, cross-project initiatives in OpenStack <https://doughellmann.com/blog/2017/04/20/lessons-learned-from-working-on-large-scale-cross-project-initiatives-in-openstack/>`__ * `Boston Forum Logging Working Group Work session <https://www.openstack.org/summit/boston-2017/summit-schedule/events/18507/logging-working-group-working-session>`__ * Current log call counts and SLOC counts (below) Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: oslo.log work: dhellmann gate and publishing jobs for troubleshooting guides: TBD template for troubleshooting guide: TBD hacking validator to ensure a situation ID document exists: TBD documenting situations and allocating IDs: TBD Work Items ---------- * Make the oslo.log formatter look for an optional situation ID field and insert it into the message if present. * Make the oslo.log OSJournalHandler emit the situation ID in the MESSAGE_ID field. * Make the oslo.log JSONFormatter emit the situation ID in its own field. * Create gate and publishing jobs for Troubleshooting Guides. * Create template for Troubleshooting Guide. * Add Troubleshooting Guide to each project. (We should wait for there to be useful documentation for at least one situation before doing this.) * Add hacking validation rule to ensure situation IDs are not added without documentation. * Document situations and add IDs to logging calls. * (optional) Update oslo.context to disallow setting a situation_id value. Dependencies ============ None History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Pike - Introduced Current log call counts and SLOC counts ======================================= The counts for each type of logging call and the total number of lines of python code was produced with the following script. .. code-block:: bash #!/bin/bash REPOS="" # set to a list of all official repos known for pike tmpfile="" for repo in $REPOS do if [ ! -z "$tmpfile" ] then rm -f $tmpfile fi cd ~/repos/$repo tmpfile=$(mktemp) # Get a list of the python source files that are not test files. git ls-files | grep '.py$' | grep -v -i test > $tmpfile if [ ! -s $tmpfile ] then # Empty file list means no .py files continue fi echo echo $repo egrep -i -o -h \ 'log(ging)?\.(debug|info|warn|warning|error|exception|trace|critical|setup)\(' \ $(cat $tmpfile) \ | cut -f2 -d'.' \ | cut -f1 -d'(' \ | sort \ | uniq -c nlines=$( cloc --progress-rate=0 --csv --quiet --list-file $tmpfile | \ cut -f5 -d, | tail -n 1) echo " $nlines lines" done The output from the script above: :: openstack/aodh 38 debug 13 error 14 exception 14 info 1 setup 8 warning 4599 commit_message:
[docs] Fix Newton deploy guide link

The current link goes to the index page for
all projects. This patch fixes it to point
directly at the OSA guide.

The link reference is also moved up into the
same location in the list as that used for
Ocata.

The protocol is also changed to HTTPS as all
docs websites are now published via HTTPS and
HTTP queries are redirected from HTTP to HTTPS.

Change-Id: I34b93adf12afc0c289b61c25a497314fc81c220e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/59/463959/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: The OpenStack-Ansible Newton Deployment Guide is available for review: * `OpenStack-Ansible Newton Deployment Guide`_ .. _OpenStack-Ansible Newton Deployment Guide: http://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/newton/

commit_message:
[docs] Fix Ocata deploy guide link

The current link goes to the index page for
all projects. This patch fixes it to point
directly at the OSA guide.

The protocol is also changed to HTTPS as all
docs websites are now published via HTTPS and
HTTP queries are redirected from HTTP to HTTPS.

Change-Id: I1797e11dc72b473d46a7517a553dc7199178874f

commit_message:
Use configdrive in templates

Use nova configdrive to bypass nova userdata size hardcoded to 64k

userdata are not serve with metadataapi but inside a mounted iso drive
by nova that is cloud-init compliant.

Change-Id: I32590e015220959400cb2af980abe1c6f8bd6583
Related-Bug: #1680900

Correct "openstack floating ip delete" command

- Correct "openstack floating ip delete" command

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/52/464152/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Delete floating IP addressesTo delete a floating IP addresses, run: $ openstack floating ip delete <floating-ip> $ openstack floating ip delete 192.168.1.56
deleted_lines: .. note:: You should use a free IP addresses that is valid for your network. If you are not sure, at least try to avoid the DHCP address range: - Pick a small range (/29 gives an 8 address range, 6 of which will be usable). - Use :command:`nmap` to check a range's availability. For example, 192.168.1.56/29 represents a small range of addresses (192.168.1.56-63, with 57-62 usable), and you could run the command :command:`nmap -sn 192.168.1.56/29` to check whether the entire range is currently unused. Bulk delete floating IP addressesTo delete a range of floating IP addresses, run: $ openstack floating ip delete RANGE_TO_DELETE $ openstack floating ip delete 192.168.1.56/29

commit_message:
Use master libs for shade functional-libs

The purpose of this job is to test that latest libs work with
newton devstack. We don't want to install devstack from branch
tips. Rather, we want to install branch tips (of master) into our
functional venv. This means we need zuul to prepare the repo states
for the libraries based on master, even though devstack is set with
a branch-override of stable/newton. It should be ok though, since
we did not set DEVSTACK_PROJECT_FROM_GIT for the projects as well.

Change-Id: I7de309504b5f52c1f7da64d3924efbb6db9a02e7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/35/464335/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # The purpose of this job is to test that latest libs work with # newton devstack. We don't want to install devstack from branch # tips. We want to install branch tips (of master) into our # functional venv. export OVERRIDE_OS_CLIENT_CONFIG_PROJECT_BRANCH="master" export OVERRIDE_KEYSTONEAUTH_PROJECT_BRANCH="master" export OVERRIDE_PYTHON_NOVACLIENT_PROJECT_BRANCH="master" export OVERRIDE_PYTHON_KEYSTONECLIENT_PROJECT_BRANCH="master"

Adding HAProxy backend options

Support for backend options is added to support
arbitrary haproxy options like http-check or tcp-check

Related-To: #1681695
(cherry picked from commit 406077ac460f972c7e3352e1ebc2073840962e6e)

Added link to Create Action form Edit

The Create Workbook and Create Workflow form has links to the
Workflow Language syntax. Similarly, link to the syntax for
creating action is added to the Create Action form.

commit_message:
Prevent tests' unmocked access to utils.execute()

This change introduces a new base test class that mocks out
utils.execute and forces an exception if it gets called.
This has rooted out many tests that were doing this as a side effect of
calling other functions, doing things like modprobe and running iscsi
on the host's actual machine.

The tests are all now appropriately patched in places where this was
happening, and the new base class permanently prevents this from
accidentally happening again.

If you really want to call utils.execute() then you need to re-mock it
in your unit test.

Change-Id: Idf87d09a9c01a6bfe2767f8becabe65c02983518

information with examples.

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/26/464626/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * ServiceNetMap: Mapping of service_name -> network name. Default mappings for service to network names are defined in ../network/service_net_map.j2.yaml, which may be overridden via ServiceNetMap values added to a user environment file via parameter_defaults. * EndpointMap: Mapping of service endpoint -> protocol. Contains a mapping of endpoint data generated for all services, based on the data included in ../network/endpoints/endpoint_data.yaml. * DefaultPasswords: Mapping of service -> default password. Used to pass some passwords from the parent templates, this is a legacy interface and should not be used by new services. be deployed in multiple roles. This is an internal parameter (should not be set via environment file), which is fetched from the name attribute of the roles_data.yaml template. applied. Using the format "<RoleName>Parameters" in the parameter_defaults of user environment file, parameters can be provided for a specific role. For example, in order to provide a parameter specific to "Compute" role, below is the format:: parameter_defaults: ComputeParameters: Param1: value
deleted_lines: * ServiceNetMap: Mapping of service_name -> network name. Typically set via parameter_defaults in the resource registry. This mapping overrides those in ServiceNetMapDefaults. * EndpointMap: Mapping of service endpoint -> protocol. Typically set via parameter_defaults in the resource registry. * DefaultPasswords: Mapping of service -> default password. Used to help pass top level passwords managed by Heat into services. be deployed in multiple roles. applied.

commit_message:
Bump Ryu to 4.11

neutron-dynamic-routing uses test utility in ryu on scenario tests.
And we want to use the test utility with 'docker network' as in
xenial we can use 'docker network' by default.
But ryu 4.10 and earier versions have bug for 'docker network'.

Change-Id: Idac9af7e80e724443ec021f2529882e80b91f61f

commit_message:
Add dnsmasq-flags to charm-neutron-openvswitch

Add a new option to provide the ability to specify flags in the
dnsmasq.conf file. This allows users to configure the dnsmasq
processes used by the neutron-dhcp-agent when local dhcp and
metadata are enabled for provider networks.

Change-Id: I2bab8a00322afb0f81986001c86f0ef4fc535651
Closes-Bug: #1684231
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-neutron-openvswitch refs/changes/22/461922/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: dnsmasq-flags: type: string default: description: | Comma-separated list of key=value config flags with the additional dhcp options for neutron dnsmasq. Note, this option is only valid when enable-local-dhcp-and-metadata option is set to True.

commit_message:
Set maximum pylint version

It turns out that pylint 1.7 introduced additional checks that
are failing against fuel-qa code. It is reasonable to prevent
new checks for stable branches and the best way to do so is to
pin pylint version.

Change-Id: Iae7506dacd93be9a76e1800ab3091dc715fb8ed5
Closes-bug: #1690410

subject: Cast time-to-live values to int
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-14 00:47:44.000000000', 'files': ['unit_tests/test_ceilometer_contexts.py', 'lib/ceilometer_contexts.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceilometer/commit/09bb38e488026f2755d12a3e471364bd490df240', 'message': "Cast time-to-live values to int

For large integer values, Juju can choose to return the number
in scientific notation. This causes the python code loading the
config data to return a floating point number instead of an
integer. Floating point values in ceilometer's configuration file
will prevent ceilometer from starting.

This change forces the type to an integer, allowing users to

Change-Id: I8e29e6868b4c4a4ae20ad87ab585508fd321261c
Closes-Bug: #1651645
"}]
commit_message:
Cast time-to-live values to int

For large integer values, Juju can choose to return the number
in scientific notation. This causes the python code loading the
config data to return a floating point number instead of an
integer. Floating point values in ceilometer's configuration file
will prevent ceilometer from starting.

This change forces the type to an integer, allowing users to
specify large ttl values.

Change-Id: I8e29e6868b4c4a4ae20ad87ab585508fd321261c
Closes-Bug: #1651645
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-ceilometer refs/changes/92/456792/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Make sure to cast the time-to-live events to integer values. # For large enough numbers, Juju returns the value in scientific # notation which causes python to treat the number as a float # value, which in turn causes ceilometer to fail to start. # See LP#1651645 for more details. 'metering_time_to_live': int(config('metering-time-to-live')), 'event_time_to_live': int(config('event-time-to-live')),

commit_message:
[WIP] Selectively disable deployment resources

Maps deployment resources to a new nested stack that contains logic to
selectively disable deployment resources for given server(s) based on
the value of the DeploymentServerBlacklist parameter.

The parameters is a list of dicts mapping deployment resource names to
server names. Both the deployment name and server names can be specified
with regular expressions. In the event multiple mappings match given
names, the first match wins. This allows flexibility to disable
deployments on groups of servers or invidividual servers.

Partially implements blueprint disable-deployments

Change-Id: I57e2c9f6f38991bbf76ced0e7ce41b0133250961
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/81/442681/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
[WIP] Pluggable deployment resources

Add a mapping from the different deployment resources to TripleO
sepcific resources. The TripleO resources are mapped to just the
OS::Heat deployment resources by default.

While not strictly necessary (one could map the OS::Heat resources to a
nested stack directly in the resource registry), this makes the
abstraction more explicit in the event a user wanted to make use of the
OS::Heat resources in an extra config template without it being
remapped.

Implements blueprint disable-deployments

Change-Id: I1661336e27fa6bf38556eca5444bc0455b7f040c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/80/442680/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add LSYNCD_OPTIONS for CentOS

The lsyncd daemon on CentOS can't find the location of its
configuration file because the LSYNCD_OPTIONS variable is
missing in the defaults file.

commit_message:
Change neutron-metadata number of workers determination method

neutron-metadata number of workers will be taken from NeutronWorkers parameter
if not empty. when empty, all keys related to NeutronWorkers value will be
set with empty dictionary instead empty string ({}).

Change-Id: I18347639c188bbf085e2f3c739465e52c94b9d77
Closes-bug: #1689571

commit_message:
etcd3: fix test run

pifpaf always exports the URL as being etcd:// which always loads the etcd
driver, and never the etcd3 driver. Therefore, it's not currently tested.

This fixes that by exporting a variable in tox that will allow us to replace
the URL correctly.

Change-Id: Id4f54bb1f729498a39e9bf58da8ee01562c4344b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tooz refs/changes/36/463636/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
coordination: factorize common async result futures code

Many drivers leverage concurrent.futures to return result, so let's just
factorize all of that in a same place.

Change-Id: Ibdec36912b553eb4b76c9f99619c171bc41766bb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tooz refs/changes/35/463635/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: from concurrent import futuresclass RedisFutureResult(coordination.CoordAsyncResult): """Redis asynchronous result that references a future.""" def __init__(self, fut): self._fut = fut def get(self, timeout=10): try: # Late translate the common failures since the redis client # may throw things that we can not catch in the callbacks where # it is used (especially one that uses the transaction # method). with _translate_failures(): return self._fut.result(timeout=timeout) except futures.TimeoutError as e: utils.raise_with_cause(coordination.OperationTimedOut, encodeutils.exception_to_unicode(e), cause=e) def done(self): return self._fut.done()

subject: Remove trailing slash in nginx config
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-10 13:55:27.000000000', 'files': ['templates/nova-placement-nginx.conf.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_nova/commit/b3c6035b7a1833a459fa0b5fd74ddcddd3740e00', 'message': "Remove trailing slash in nginx config

The nginx configuration file passes along traffic to the placement
API if the URI is '/placement/' but the service is registered with
keystone as just '/placement' (no trailing slash). This causes
nginx to send back the default page when nova services try to talk
to the placement API.

This patch fixes the nginx configuration to match the URI for the
registered service.

Closes-Bug: 1689824
Change-Id: I309730a6daa8c3ea15fca78ab9ce910383019869
"}]
commit_message:
Remove trailing slash in nginx config

The nginx configuration file passes along traffic to the placement
API if the URI is '/placement/' but the service is registered with
keystone as just '/placement' (no trailing slash). This causes
nginx to send back the default page when nova services try to talk
to the placement API.

This patch fixes the nginx configuration to match the URI for the
registered service.

Closes-Bug: 1689824
Change-Id: I309730a6daa8c3ea15fca78ab9ce910383019869
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_nova refs/changes/60/463760/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

[doc] Add flags description to scenario doc

Add the grids with description of each flag, which we can use
when we run tests with tox

Change-Id: I1b10f73f0f7ece6d14c6dcdb6243893747dc0153

commit_message:
Fix lbaasv2 in service_plugins

If enable lbaas,service_plugins value is 'neutron_lbaas.services
.loadbalancer.plugin:LoadBalancerPluginv2'.
It throw warning for 'stevedore.named [-]Could not load neutron_lbaas
.services.loadbalancer.plugin.LoadBalancerPluginv2'

Closes-Bug: #1690694

Change-Id: I38d61405710ca88fbdb3cfd72a534986cf933195

commit_message:
Install libselinux-python on RHEL

libselinux-python is needed on RHEL based distros for ansible
to work properly.

Change-Id: Ia5054b574710d7688c1641110af89f0457609281

commit_message:
Bump the tripleo-ui change patchset number

From time to time we need to rebase the dummy change in tripleo-ui to
keep it building with DLRN in our quickstart gating tests. This is
another one of those occasions.

Change-Id: I7b55a86551f2e57dac5b564b13492e529c6db8f1

commit_message:
Use prettier for linting

Run the code through eslint and prettier.  Eslint checks structural
things (e.g. console.log), and prettier checks stylistic things.

The "npm run lint" script will fail if your code isn't properly
formatted with prettier.

You can use "npm run prettier" to format your code.

Change-Id: Ie44e17d29e59cb4e3089ade2fb2b20f8213b5853

added_lines: return when.try(getServiceUrl, 'heat').then(serviceUrl => { let requestAttributes = _.merge( { url: `${serviceUrl}${path}`, headers: { 'X-Auth-Token': getAuthTokenId() }, crossOrigin: true, contentType: 'application/json', type: 'json', method: 'GET' }, additionalAttributes ); return this.defaultRequest( `/stacks/${stack.stack_name}/${stack.id}/resources/${resourceName}` ); return this.defaultRequest( `/stacks/${stack.stack_name}/${stack.id}/environment` );
deleted_lines: return when.try(getServiceUrl, 'heat').then((serviceUrl) => { let requestAttributes = _.merge({ url: `${serviceUrl}${path}`, headers: { 'X-Auth-Token': getAuthTokenId() }, crossOrigin: true, contentType: 'application/json', type: 'json', method: 'GET' }, additionalAttributes); return this.defaultRequest(`/stacks/${stack.stack_name}/${stack.id}/resources/${resourceName}`); return this.defaultRequest(`/stacks/${stack.stack_name}/${stack.id}/environment`);

subject: Add role specific information to the service template
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-02-24 15:56:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/6e92d997f4ddf1b6992f5a786a16e43225d3bf84', 'message': 'WIP: Add RoleName as a new parameter for Services

parameters from environemt files.

Change-Id: I72376a803ec6b2ed93903cc0c95a6ffce718b6dc
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-03-13 11:45:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/2def799d65e5f6119cc7c391cef1843ca3eeb597', 'message': 'WIP: Add RoleName as a new parameter for Services

'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-03-14 05:32:53.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/811618da07a397d25e363abb7cc777d85d4f9ded', 'message': 'WIP: Add RoleName as a new parameter for Services

Change-Id: I72376a803ec6b2ed93903cc0c95a6ffce718b6dc
'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2017-03-15 06:58:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/1ccfa9564fcc4dc4f815b6c948c778ff4fb490c7', 'message': 'WIP: Add role specific information to the service template

Two new parameters - RoleName and RoleParameters, are added to the
service template. RoleName provides the role name of on which the
current instance of the service is being applied on. RoleParameters
provides the list of parameters which are configured specific to the
role in the environment file, like below:

  parameters_default:
   NovaReservedHostMemory: 2048
    ComputeSriovParameters:
      NovaReservedHostMemory: 4096
    ComputeOvsDpdkParameters:
      NovaReservedHostMemory: 6144

In above sample, the cluster contains 3 roles - Compute, ComputeSriov
and ComputeOvsDpdk. The parameter which supports role specific
configuration, should find the parameter first in in the
RoleParameters list, if not found, then the default (for all roles)
should be used.

Change-Id: I72376a803ec6b2ed93903cc0c95a6ffce718b6dc

'}, {'number': 24, 'created': '2017-04-07 17:54:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/d0ef90f95a5b9360b434063d6db3ee9d52c3a4ce', 'message': 'WIP: Add role specific information to the service template

When a service is enabled on multiple roles, the parameters for the
service will be global. This change enables an option to provide
role specific parameter to services and other templates.

Two new parameters - RoleName and RoleParameters, are added to the
service template. RoleName provides the role name of on which the
current instance of the service is being applied on. RoleParameters
provides the list of parameters which are configured specific to the
role in the environment file, like below:

  parameters_default:
      # Default value for all roles
      NovaReservedHostMemory: 2048
      ComputeDpdkParameters:
          # Applied only to ComputeSriov role
          NovaReservedHostMemory: 4096

In above sample, the cluster contains 2 roles - Compute, ComputeDpdk.
The values of ComputeDpdkParameters will be passed on to the templates
as RoleParameters while creating the stack for ComputeDpdk role. The
parameter which supports role specific configuration, should find the
parameter first in in the RoleParameters list, if not found, then the
default (for all roles) should be used.

Change-Id: I72376a803ec6b2ed93903cc0c95a6ffce718b6dc
'}, {'number': 25, 'created': '2017-04-07 17:57:10.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/58be43775fcfb87841511a347b12111d1f78eedb', 'message': 'WIP: Add role specific information to the service template

When a service is enabled on multiple roles, the parameters for the
service will be global. This change enables an option to provide
role specific parameter to services and other templates.

Two new parameters - RoleName and RoleParameters, are added to the
service template. RoleName provides the role name of on which the
current instance of the service is being applied on. RoleParameters
provides the list of parameters which are configured specific to the
role in the environment file, like below:

commit_message:
Add role specific information to the service template

When a service is enabled on multiple roles, the parameters for the
service will be global. This change enables an option to provide
role specific parameter to services and other templates.

Two new parameters - RoleName and RoleParameters, are added to the
service template. RoleName provides the role name of on which the
current instance of the service is being applied on. RoleParameters
provides the list of parameters which are configured specific to the
role in the environment file, like below:

  parameters_default:
      # Default value for applied to all roles
      NovaReservedHostMemory: 2048
      ComputeDpdkParameters:
          # Applied only to ComputeDpdk role
          NovaReservedHostMemory: 4096

In above sample, the cluster contains 2 roles - Compute, ComputeDpdk.
The values of ComputeDpdkParameters will be passed on to the templates
as RoleParameters while creating the stack for ComputeDpdk role. The
parameter which supports role specific configuration, should find the
parameter first in in the RoleParameters list, if not found, then the
default (for all roles) should be used.
Implements: blueprint tripleo-derive-parameters

Change-Id: I72376a803ec6b2ed93903cc0c95a6ffce718b6dc

commit_message:
Override bgp_pulse in test to be event-driven

bgp_pulse, in bgp_service, fires the sync method every constant amount
of time. In the tests, we want to verify this method is called. Since we
use loopingcall, which is tested, we can limit ourselves only to verify
the behaviour we want, and assume the method is called when we need it.

This change makes bgp_pulse event-driven, i.e. we can fire an event to
tell bgp_pulse to run, and therefore not have to wait for the timeout
(which doesn't always work and produces false positives).

Change-Id: I7f0bb3c89d6e1f198a8b9bd28e8c356033a234c6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow refs/changes/34/464334/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import threading from eventlet import greenthreadclass LoopingCallByEvent(object): def __init__(self, func): self.func = func self.thread = None self.event = None self.is_running = False def start(self, *args): self.event = threading.Event() self.is_running = True self.thread = greenthread.spawn(self.run) def stop(self): self.is_running = False def fire(self): self.event.set() def run(self): self.event.wait() while self.is_running: self.func() self.event.clear() self.event.wait() self.bgp_service.bgp_pulse = LoopingCallByEvent( self.bgp_service.sync_data_from_nb_db) self.bgp_service.bgp_pulse.fire() eventlet.sleep(1) self.bgp_service.bgp_pulse.fire() eventlet.sleep(1) self.bgp_service.bgp_pulse.fire() eventlet.sleep(1) self.bgp_service.bgp_pulse.fire() eventlet.sleep(1) self.assertTrue(self.bgp_service.bgp_driver.advertise_route.called) self.bgp_service.bgp_pulse.fire() eventlet.sleep(1) self.assertTrue(self.bgp_service.bgp_driver.withdraw_route.called)
deleted_lines: eventlet.sleep(0) eventlet.sleep(0) eventlet.sleep(cfg.CONF.df_bgp.pulse_interval + 1) test_utils.wait_until_true( lambda: self.bgp_service.bgp_driver.advertise_route.called, cfg.CONF.df_bgp.pulse_interval * 2, 1) test_utils.wait_until_true( lambda: self.bgp_service.bgp_driver.withdraw_route.called, cfg.CONF.df_bgp.pulse_interval * 2, 1)

commit_message:
Add uuid to service.update notification payload

Now that the services table has a uuid field and we'll be exposing
that out of the REST API, we should include the uuid in the
service.update notification payload.

Part of blueprint service-hyper-uuid-in-api

Change-Id: I8c400086a8dce9317a39f7e65c8d098d93af335d

commit_message:
objects: add ComputeNode.get_by_uuid method

The HostAPI is going to use this to uniquely identify a host
across cells.

Depends-On: I940979d85fc105c9733ae19c406e85debe8fdffb

Part of blueprint service-hyper-uuid-in-api

Change-Id: I21f4b18e4554e9e912496e623461129196c72852
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/48/461448/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @mock.patch.object(db, 'compute_node_get_by_uuid') def test_get_by_uuid(self, get_mock): get_mock.return_value = fake_compute_node compute = compute_node.ComputeNode.get_by_uuid( self.context, uuidsentinel.compute_node_uuid) self.compare_obj(compute, fake_compute_node, subs=self.subs(), comparators=self.comparators()) get_mock.assert_called_once_with( self.context, uuidsentinel.compute_node_uuid)

sudo yum clean all; sudo rm -rf /etc/yum.repos.d/delorean*; sudo rm -rf /etc/yum.repos.d/*.rpmsave; export CURRENT_RDO_MIRROR=`curl --silent https://trunk.rdoproject.org/centos7/current/delorean.repo | grep baseurl | cut -d= -f2` export CURRENT_TRIPLEO_MIRROR=`curl --silent https://trunk.rdoproject.org/centos7/current-tripleo/delorean.repo | grep baseurl | cut -d= -f2` # If running tripleo-quickstart in OpenStack Infra, let's try to use AFS mirrors if [[ -e /etc/nodepool/provider ]]; then source /etc/nodepool/provider; export NODEPOOL_MIRROR_HOST=$(echo "http://mirror.$NODEPOOL_REGION.$NODEPOOL_CLOUD.openstack.org" | tr '[:upper:]' '[:lower:]'); export CURRENT_RDO_MIRROR=${CURRENT_RDO_MIRROR/https:\/\/trunk.rdoproject.org/$NODEPOOL_MIRROR_HOST:8080/rdo} export CURRENT_TRIPLEO_MIRROR=${CURRENT_RDO_MIRROR/https:\/\/trunk.rdoproject.org/$NODEPOOL_MIRROR_HOST:8080/rdo} fi # Otherwise, fallback to official mirrors provided by CentOS. export NODEPOOL_MIRROR_HOST="${NODEPOOL_MIRROR_HOST:-http://mirror.centos.org}" repos: - type: generic reponame: delorean filename: delorean.repo baseurl: $CURRENT_TRIPLEO_MIRROR hash_url: https://trunk.rdoproject.org/centos7-master/current-tripleo/delorean.repo - type: generic reponame: delorean-current filename: delorean-current.repo baseurl: $CURRENT_RDO_MIRROR priority: 10 includepkgs: - diskimage-builder - instack - instack-undercloud - os-apply-config - os-collect-config - os-net-config - os-refresh-config - python-tripleoclient - openstack-tripleo-common - openstack-tripleo-heat-templates - openstack-tripleo-image-elements - openstack-tripleo - openstack-tripleo-puppet-elements - openstack-puppet-modules - openstack-tripleo-ui - puppet-* - type: file filename: delorean-deps.repo down_url: https://trunk.rdoproject.org/centos7-master/delorean-deps.repo - type: generic reponame: centos-qemu filename: centos-qemu.repo baseurl: ${NODEPOOL_MIRROR_HOST}/centos/7/virt/x86_64/kvm-common/ - type: generic reponame: centos-ceph-jewel filename: centos-ceph-jewel.repo baseurl: ${NODEPOOL_MIRROR_HOST}/centos/7/storage/x86_64/ceph-jewel/ - type: generic reponame: centos-opstools filename: centos-opstools.repo baseurl: ${NODEPOOL_MIRROR_HOST}/centos/7/opstools/x86_64/ repo_cmd_after: | {% if not enable_opstools_repo|default(false)|bool %}sudo yum-config-manager --save --setopt centos-opstools.enable=0; {%endif %} sudo yum-config-manager --disable rdo-qemu-ev; sudo rpm -e epel-release || true; sudo yum remove -y rdo-release || true; sudo rm -rf /etc/yum.repos.d/*.rpmsave; sudo yum repolist; sudo yum update -y

commit_message:
Don't overwrite tht_dir for upgrades to master

Overwriting this broke mixed version upgrade [1], which tried to copy
t-h-t to `/home/stack//usr/share/openstack-tripleo-heat-templates`:

https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras/blob/b1a1f010db17a4abf9281748ee36bcbe0eee6c88/roles/overcloud-upgrade/tasks/pre-undercloud.yml#L39

Setting tht_dir like this is suspicious given how tht_dir is used in
rest of the code, and this should probably be fully removed eventually,
but i'm keeping it at least for Ocata as i suspect that there might be
some jobs relying on the semi-broken behavior (which probably aren't
running a mixed version upgrade, otherwise they'd fail).

In case we are using a composable scenario which didn't exist
previously, we copy in the composable scenario from the RPM location, so
that OOOQ can find the expected environment file without needing to
backport composable scenario env files to older releases.

Change-Id: Ib3fdaa87c211545f835afb1c95e4d13debba2827

commit_message:
multinode-container-upgrade.yaml usable for mixed upgrade

We need Docker service mapping defined and set to OS::Heat::None so that
we can reuse multinode-container-upgrade.yaml service list both for
initial deployment and for the upgrade. The upgrade will not be broken
by this as its env files are being passed later on the command line, and
they'll take priority and effectively enable the Docker service on
upgrade.

Another change we need for mixed upgrade is to add the TripleoPackages
service, which will take care of updating RPMs on the bare metal and
prevent docker installation from failing with outdated
puppet-tripleo ("Could not find class ::tripleo::profile::base::docker").

Related-Bug: #1685795
Closes-Bug: #1689772
Change-Id: Idb6917f22d0e9f74f8853972c6a08bffb01be410

added_lines: # NOTE: This is needed because of upgrades from Ocata to Pike. We # deploy the initial environment with Ocata templates, and # overcloud-resource-registry.yaml there doesn't have this Docker # mapping at all. After we stop CI'ing Ocata->Pike upgrade, we can # remove this. OS::TripleO::Services::Docker: OS::Heat::None

commit_message:
Create openstack-zuul-jobs / openstack-zuul-roles projects

As we continue with zuulv3, we are ready to start our first steps
towards writing jobs in ansible. As a result, we need a new
untrusted-project for zuul, which will allow dynamic reconfiguration
of jobs. We do not want to use project-config, as it is consider a
config-project and does not support dynamic reconfiguration.

These repos will be under the openstack-infra project.

Change-Id: Ie277f43a4032da24cccf008e8e3e66cc4c678a08

commit_message:
feature-classification: a common lib for FeatCl frameworks

Create a new repo to contain the frameworks for feature
classification. So that all projects can use the frameworks for
their own implementations.

Based on discussions found here:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/330027/

Depends-On: I914c23ba4298c91583bbb54de4bf3cfe092ef9e6

Change-Id: I5117c2f49860ce68b52035d95bd90684c6122924

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-08 10:38:26.000000000', 'files': ['tasks/lxc_net.yml', 'templates/lxc-net-suse-bridge.cfg.j2', 'templates/lxc-net-suse-routes.cfg.j2'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_hosts/commit/583337b69b29ded1b767c5356118d4472db41957', 'message': "Fix container bridge networking on SUSE

The GATEWAY attribute does not exist on SUSE so we need to add the
default gateway to an ifroute file. Moreover, we drop the DEVICE
attribute which also doesn't exist on SUSE ifcfg files and we add
STARTMODE='auto' to instruct wicked to automatically configure the
interface on every boot. Finally we switch STP to 'off' since there
is only a single bridge accessible from containers.

Change-Id: I9c09e2882614f89cb944a623e7b97298d4bec541
"}]
commit_message:
Fix container bridge networking on SUSE

The GATEWAY attribute does not exist on SUSE so we need to add the
default gateway to an ifroute file. Moreover, we drop the DEVICE
attribute which also doesn't exist on SUSE ifcfg files and we add
STARTMODE='auto' to instruct wicked to automatically configure the
interface on every boot. Finally we switch STP to 'off' since there
is only a single bridge accessible from containers.

Change-Id: I9c09e2882614f89cb944a623e7b97298d4bec541

commit_message:
vars: Use lxc_net_bridge instead of hardcoded lxcbr0

'lxc_net_bridge' holds the name of the bridge interface for the lxc
containers so we need to use that one instead of the hardcoded 'lxcbr0'
value.

Change-Id: I8f7b01f90cf87f20092d83ee81689cae79b2477d

commit_message:
Release notes for "evaluate_env"

Change-Id: I9a164e317d3a50a2ddb42e5b20c7c2c7bdaf679f
(cherry picked from commit 0415a7c44ba0c0fb66969c11aacab696cbcdb8a3)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/55/464555/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - When we pass a workflow environment to workflow parameters using 'env' Mistral first evaluates it assuming that it can contain expressions (YAQL/Jinja) For example, one environment variable can be expressed through the other. In some cases it causes problems. For example, if the environment is too big and has many expressions, especially something like <% $ %> or <% env() %>. Also, in some cases we don't want any evaluations to happen if we want to have some informative text in the environment containing expressions. In order to address that the 'evaluate_env' workflow parameter was added, defaulting to True for backwards compatibility. If it's set to False then it disables evaluation of expressions in the environment.

subject: Add 'evaluate_env' workflow parameter
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-15 07:20:21.000000000', 'files': ['mistral/workflow/data_flow.py', 'mistral/tests/unit/engine/test_environment.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/mistral/commit/8173522616f5b63a221e41212c55a904c397101f', 'message': "Add 'evaluate_env' workflow parameter

* This parameter, if set to False, prevents from evaluating

  True for backwards compatibility. In some cases, it guarantees
  safety from blowing size of the evaluated objects (e.g. if
  there are expressions in it like <% $ %> and <% env() %>). Or
  if we simply don't want to evaluate it because we want to have
  a text in the environment containing expressions as informative.

Change-Id: I116004e9e2d0269fc69e39b552165f6e0720148a
Closes-Bug: #1690319
(cherry picked from commit aa1790ca7442c45019a91f9ba604bc5dcb61fa50)
"}]
commit_message:
Add 'evaluate_env' workflow parameter

* This parameter, if set to False, prevents from evaluating
  expressions in a workflow environment. By default, it's set to
  True for backwards compatibility. In some cases, it guarantees
  safety from blowing size of the evaluated objects (e.g. if
  there are expressions in it like <% $ %> and <% env() %>). Or
  if we simply don't want to evaluate it because we want to have
  a text in the environment containing expressions as informative.

Change-Id: I116004e9e2d0269fc69e39b552165f6e0720148a
Closes-Bug: #1690319
(cherry picked from commit aa1790ca7442c45019a91f9ba604bc5dcb61fa50)

added_lines: from mistral.services import workflows as wf_service def test_evaluate_env_parameter(self): wf_text = """--- version: '2.0' wf: tasks: task1: action: std.noop publish: var1: <% env().var1 %> var2: <% env().var2 %> """ wf_service.create_workflows(wf_text) env = { "var1": "val1", "var2": "<% env().var1 %>" } # Run with 'evaluate_env' set to True. wf_ex = self.engine.start_workflow( 'wf', {}, env=env, evaluate_env=True ) self.await_workflow_success(wf_ex.id) with db_api.transaction(): wf_ex = db_api.get_workflow_execution(wf_ex.id) t = self._assert_single_item(wf_ex.task_executions, name='task1') self.assertDictEqual( { "var1": "val1", "var2": "val1" }, t.published ) # Run with 'evaluate_env' set to False. wf_ex = self.engine.start_workflow( 'wf', {}, env=env, evaluate_env=False ) self.await_workflow_success(wf_ex.id) with db_api.transaction(): wf_ex = db_api.get_workflow_execution(wf_ex.id) t = self._assert_single_item(wf_ex.task_executions, name='task1') self.assertDictEqual( { "var1": "val1", "var2": "<% env().var1 %>" }, t.published )

commit_message:
Add hide_args=True to @profiler.trace() where it may cause problems

* Without hide_args=True parameter @profiler.trace() works much
  slower because it gets string representation of decorated method
  parameters internally. Adding it slightly improves performance.

Change-Id: I75a8fecd2e37b1d25c6f70501711e709c2d2ae25
(cherry picked from commit 2c6737b74c69d0da7082f00ff94d114ac7af423d)

commit_message:
remove python dependency when master/minion nodes make certificates.

Currently, python2 is used when make certs.
removing python2 dependency  is more flexible.
using printf, awk, and grep enable master/minion nodes need not python dependency.

Change-Id: Ib2307eeb58bda9f035da3bd6f2dd047eacfcf3fc

commit_message:
OVSBridge: add --strict to allow priority in delete_flows

n8g-sfc currently has its own variant of OVSBridge to allow the use
of priority in a delete_flows call

This change is meant to make this available outside n8g-sfc and
simplify n8g-sfc code.

This change adds a 'strict' boolean parameter to mod_flow and delete_flows
that results in ovs-ofctl to be run with --strict for del-flows and
mod-flows actions.  When strict is set, the use of priority is allowed
and hence not rejected anymore.

Note that for batched actions in a deffered bridge, we disallow mixing
calls with strict and without strict, which can't be translated in one CLI
call.

Needed-By: I3bf939590dd43bff685f133bff86eb7e9068de91
Change-Id: I289d546780f10dc1002ab6bc2e1b38c9ef2d728f

Change-Id: I2faf8f3541fc800ea61c417e5575f4a56a83665b
Closes-Bug: #1620696
'}]
commit_message:
Copy template version when update fails

When an update fails, we may have copy some chunk of resources or
parameters to the new template. If the version was updated and the new
resources require the version, this can lead to a state where the stack
is in an usable state. This synchronizes the version when a failure
happens.

Change-Id: I2faf8f3541fc800ea61c417e5575f4a56a83665b
Closes-Bug: #1620696
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/97/458497/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Remove log translations in keystonemiddle

Log messages are no longer being translated. This removes all use of
the _LE, _LI, and _LW translation markers to simplify logging and to
avoid confusion with new contributions.

See:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-i18n/2016-November/002574.html
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-March/113365.html

Change-Id: Ie3e993b142924a71b2ee08e95a77ccf5cf584f4a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystonemiddleware refs/changes/43/464543/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: msg = 'Unable to discover target information because '\ 'service catalog is missing. Either the incoming '\ 'request does not contain an auth token or auth '\ 'token does not contain a service catalog. commit_message:
Add endpoint type for image cache command

Currently there is no possibility to specify endpoint type when
using cache manage client. By default we are trying to reach
publicURL endpoint which is not true in most of the cases since
internalURL/adminURL is usually used for such client.

Closes-Bug: #1634486
Change-Id: I22685f98951286943d3ce87a617e82f28a342c47
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/59/391859/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Do not use default domain if domain name specified

Previously, swift client always specified project and user domain by
default if it was not specified. When we introduced keystoneclient
to use trusts we had to specify it by default. Otherwise, many
installations could be broken. But we don't need to specify
these defaults if user domain name or id is specified already.

Closes-Bug: #1620999

Change-Id: I70cb27fe893dd51b6c8c123bd535c168b7169d70

commit_message:
Add possibility to pass objects for API v2

Now glanceclient v2 is accepting only string uuids as image_id.
We need to provide possibility to pass image objects to API v2.
So user doesn't need to bother what he passed: image_id or image
object.

Change-Id: Ia84d0f78eb0097e5f99a9f8051419d44df5df189
Closes-Bug:#1475001

commit_message:
[WIP] [Poc] Add possibility to specify swift url from config

During code re-factoring we relied on service
catalog functionality to receive swift endpoint for
single-tenant store(swiftclient did the same previously).
It turns out that if we provide an endpoint to swiftclient
it may prefer it and not to call service catalog for endpoint
(honestly, I didn't tested that yet).
There are users who rely on this functionality, so we need to
provide possibility to pass preauthurl to swiftclient
together with auth_url and other credentials.

Change-Id: I154f39d74bd696de01cbd6881d942fd1b6d614e8

added_lines: [django] debug = true # WEBROOT is the location relative to Webserver root # should end with a slash. webroot = / login_url = $webroot/auth/login/ logout_url = $webroot/auth/logout/ # LOGIN_REDIRECT_URL can be used as an alternative for # HORIZON_CONFIG.user_home, if user_home is not set. # Do not set it to '/home/', as this will cause circular redirect loop login_redirect_url = $webroot # If horizon is running in production (DEBUG is False), set this # with the list of host/domain names that the application can serve. # For more information see: # https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/settings/#allowed-hosts allowed_hosts = horizon.example.com, localhost # Set SSL proxy settings: # Pass this header from the proxy after terminating the SSL, # and don't forget to strip it from the client's request. # For more information see: # https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/ref/settings/#secure-proxy-ssl-header secure_proxy_ssl_header = HTTP_X_FORWARDED_PROTO, https # Set custom secret key: # You can either set it to a specific value or you can let horizon generate a # default secret key that is unique on this machine, e.i. regardless of the # amount of Python WSGI workers (if used behind Apache+mod_wsgi): However, # there may be situations where you would want to set this explicitly, e.g. # when multiple dashboard instances are distributed on different machines # (usually behind a load-balancer). Either you have to make sure that a session # gets all requests routed to the same dashboard instance or you set the same # SECRET_KEY for all of them. #secret_key = # We recommend you use memcached for development; otherwise after every reload # of the django development server, you will have to login again. # See the sections below cache_default = localmemcached caches = localmemcached,remotememcached # If Horizon is being served through SSL, then uncomment the following # setting to better secure the cookies from security exploits csrf_cookie_secure = true # The timezone of the server. This should correspond with the timezone # of your entire OpenStack installation, and hopefully be in UTC. time_zone = UTC # Modules that provide /auth routes that can be used to handle different types # of user authentication. Add auth plugins that require extra route handling to # this list. authentication_urls = openstack_auth.urls # DISALLOW_IFRAME_EMBED can be used to prevent Horizon from being embedded # within an iframe. Legacy browsers are still vulnerable to a Cross-Frame # Scripting (XFS) vulnerability, so this option allows extra security hardening # where iframes are not used in deployment. Default setting is True. # For more information see: # http://tinyurl.com/anticlickjack disallow_iframe_embed = true [localmemcached] backend = django.core.cache.backends.locmem.LocMemCache [remotememcached] backend = ... location = 10.0.1.201 [session] # If Horizon is being served through SSL, then uncomment the following # setting to better secure the cookies from security exploits cookie_secure = true [email] # Send email to the console by default backend = django.core.mail.backends.console.EmailBackend # Or send them to /dev/null #backend = django.core.mail.backends.dummy.EmailBackend # Configure these for your outgoing email host #host = smtp.my-company.com #port = 25 #host_user = djangomail #host_password = top-secret! [websso] # Enables keystone web single-sign-on if set to True. enabled = false # Determines which authentication choice to show as default. #initial_choice = credentials # The list of authentication mechanisms which include keystone # federation protocols and identity provider/federation protocol # mapping keys (WEBSSO_IDP_MAPPING). Current supported protocol # IDs are 'saml2' and 'oidc' which represent SAML 2.0, OpenID # Connect respectively. # Do not remove the mandatory credentials mechanism. # Note: The last two tuples are sample mapping keys to a identity provider # and federation protocol combination (WEBSSO_IDP_MAPPING). #choices = websso_credentials, websso_oidc, websso_saml2, websso_acme_oidc, websso_acme_saml2 [websso_credentials] #name = credentials description = Keystone Credentials [websso_oidc] #name = oidc description = OpenID Connect [websso_saml2] #name = saml2 description = Security Assertion Markup Language [websso_acme_oidc] #name = acme_oidc description = ACME - OpenID Connect idp_mapping = acme,oidc [websso_acme_saml2] #name = acme_saml2 description = ACME - SAML2 idp_mapping = acme,saml2 [theme] # Change this patch to sections containing a label and static directory # containing two files: _variables.scss and _styles.scss #[theme_default] #label = Default #path = themes/default # #[theme_material] #label = Material #path = themes/material [keystone] name = native can_edit_user = true can_edit_grouop = true can_edit_project = true can_edit_domain = true can_edit_role = true [hypervisor] can_set_mount_point = false can_set_password = false requires_keypair = false enable_quotas = true [security_group] rules = all_tcp_rule, all_udp_rule, all_icmp_rule, ... ipv4_private_subnet_cidrs = 10.0.0.0/8, 192.168.0.0/16 ipv6_private_subnet_cidrs = fc00::/7 [all_tcp_rule] name = All TCP ip_protocol = tcp from_port = 1 to_port = 65535 [all_udp_rule] name = All UDP ip_protocol = udp from_port = 1 to_port = 65535 [all_icmp_rule] name = All ICMP ip_protocol = icmp from_port = -1 to_port = -1 [identity] api_version = 3 [image] api_version = 2 default_format = none formats = aki,ami,ari,docker,iso,ova,qcow2,raw,vdi,vhd,vmdk aki_description = AKI - Amazon Kernel Image ami_description = AMI - Amazon Machine Image ari_description = ARI - Amazon Ramdisk Image # etc. #reserved_custom_properties = #allow_location = false [volume] api_version = 2 enable_backup = false [data_processing] api_version = 1.1 [compute] api_version = 2 [network] using_neutron = true enable_router = true enable_quotasa = true enable_ipv6 = true enable_distributed_router = false enable_ha_router = false enable_lb = true enable_firewall = true enable_vpn = true enable_fip_topology_check = true # etc. [orchestration] enable_user_pass = true

subject: Fix warning for deprecated cert commands
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-12 18:17:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient/commit/4b6eff0b36befb6c693a7de007bf1549c6db53d9', 'message': 'Fix warning for deprecated cert commands

If3e1e40947a8ad3f665f6a96d46de8cef6a2a190 deprecated
the cert CLIs but used the wrong warning mechanism. For the
python API bindings we use the warnings module, but for the CLI

commit_message:
Fix warning for deprecated cert commands

If3e1e40947a8ad3f665f6a96d46de8cef6a2a190 deprecated
the cert CLIs but used the wrong warning mechanism. For the
python API bindings we use the warnings module, but for the CLI
we print to stderr.

Change-Id: I4dfd9e9dddbc0c7eb8c7115d2241955a630749e6

Many database IDs (Resource, WatchRule) are integers, so 0 is a valid ID
and evaluating it in a boolean context may give the wrong result for the
first entry in the table. Even for the ones that aren't (e.g. Stack) it's

Change-Id: Id95eeb5cd0f9cac82937fae48122ce5fa90ca48d
"}]
commit_message:
Explicitly compare IDs to None

Many database IDs (Resource, WatchRule) are integers, so 0 is a valid ID
and evaluating it in a boolean context may give the wrong result for the
first entry in the table. Even for the ones that aren't (e.g. Stack) it's
better to explicitly compare to None.

Change-Id: Id95eeb5cd0f9cac82937fae48122ce5fa90ca48d

commit_message:
Release notes for "evaluate_env"

Change-Id: I9a164e317d3a50a2ddb42e5b20c7c2c7bdaf679f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/60/464160/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - When we pass a workflow environment to workflow parameters using 'env' Mistral first evaluates it assuming that it can contain expressions (YAQL/Jinja) For example, one environment variable can be expressed through the other. In some cases it causes problems. For example, if the environment is too big and has many expressions, especially something like <% $ %> or <% env() %>. Also, in some cases we don't want any evaluations to happen if we want to have some informative text in the environment containing expressions. In order to address that the 'evaluate_env' workflow parameter was added, defaulting to True for backwards compatibility. If it's set to False then it disables evaluation of expressions in the environment.

commit_message:
Add 'evaluate_env' workflow parameter

* This parameter, if set to False, prevents from evaluating
  expressions in a workflow environment. By default, it's set to
  True for backwards compatibility. In some cases, it guarantees
  safety from blowing size of the evaluated objects (e.g. if
  there are expressions in it like <% $ %> and <% env() %>). Or
  if we simply don't want to evaluate it because we want to have
  a text in the environment containing expressions as informative.

Change-Id: I116004e9e2d0269fc69e39b552165f6e0720148a
Closes-Bug: #1690319
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/58/464158/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from mistral.services import workflows as wf_service def test_evaluate_env_parameter(self): wf_text = """--- version: '2.0' wf: tasks: task1: action: std.noop publish: var1: <% env().var1 %> var2: <% env().var2 %> """ wf_service.create_workflows(wf_text) env = { "var1": "val1", "var2": "<% env().var1 %>" } # Run with 'evaluate_env' set to True. wf_ex = self.engine.start_workflow('wf', {}, env=env, evaluate_env=True) self.await_workflow_success(wf_ex.id) with db_api.transaction(): wf_ex = db_api.get_workflow_execution(wf_ex.id) t = self._assert_single_item(wf_ex.task_executions, name='task1') self.assertDictEqual( { "var1": "val1", "var2": "val1" }, t.published ) # Run with 'evaluate_env' set to False. wf_ex = self.engine.start_workflow('wf', {}, env=env, evaluate_env=False) self.await_workflow_success(wf_ex.id) with db_api.transaction(): wf_ex = db_api.get_workflow_execution(wf_ex.id) t = self._assert_single_item(wf_ex.task_executions, name='task1') self.assertDictEqual( { "var1": "val1", "var2": "<% env().var1 %>" }, t.published )

commit_message:
Add hide_args=True to @profiler.trace() where it may cause problems

* Without hide_args=True parameter @profiler.trace() works much
  slower because it gets string representation of decorated method
  parameters internally. Adding it slightly improves performance.

Change-Id: I75a8fecd2e37b1d25c6f70501711e709c2d2ae25

commit_message:
Handle multi-line default values in olso-config-generator

The oslo.config file format permits multi-line values for options,
however all the lines except for the first one need to be indented.

Right now oslo-config-generator fails to take that into account, and
instead outputs the formatted value as is, adding a comment character
only to the first line, and not commenting out or indenting the
subsequent lines.

This patch tries to fix that by adding a comment character and some
indentation to every newline in the formatted value.

Change-Id: I33381c8cfb59901ce6dfc07bd662f2edb56531dd
Closes-bug: #1689594

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-08-24 06:03:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/536695186b2a99cdd6adf92fe15fb34da6d698fb', 'message': 'Add allow_empty_param_val argument to str_replace_strict function

str_replace_strict raises an error if a param is not present in the
template. However, the user may also prefer an error is raised if a
param is present but has an empty value. This may be accomodated by
setting the optional function parameter "allow_empty_param_val" to
false (the default is true). E.g.:

str_replace_strict:
  template: myvar
  params:
    myvar: { get_attr [my_resource, the_attr] }
  allow_empty_param_val: false

commit_message:
Add the HOT fuction str_replace_vstrict

The already existing str_replace_strict function raises an error if a
param is not present in the template. str_replace_vstrict, newly added
in this patch, is identical but also raises an error if any of the
params have an empty value.

Change-Id: I5407135cc0435cfbad2d18964fe2119c999f67a3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/05/359605/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: tmpl = template.Template(hot_tpl_empty) ex = self.assertRaises(TypeError, self.resolve, snippet, tmpl) self.assertIn('"str_replace" params must be strings or numbers, ' 'param jsonvar1 is not valid', six.text_type(ex)) tmpl = template.Template(hot_tpl_empty) ex = self.assertRaises(TypeError, self.resolve, snippet, tmpl) self.assertIn('"str_replace" params must be strings or numbers, ' 'param listvar1 is not valid', six.text_type(ex)) def test_str_replace_strict_missing_param_value(self): """Test str_replace_strict function allow_empty_param_val. Raise ValueError when allow_empty_param_val is False and any of the params are None or empty. """ snippet = {'str_replace_strict': {'template': 'Template var1 string var2', 'params': {'var1': 'foo', 'var2': ''}}} tmpl = template.Template(hot_newton_tpl_empty) self.assertEqual('Template foo string ', self.resolve(snippet, tmpl)) for val in (None, '', {}, []): snippet['str_replace_strict']['params']['var2'] = val snippet['str_replace_strict']['allow_empty_param_val'] = False ex = self.assertRaises(ValueError, self.resolve, snippet, tmpl) self.assertIn('str_replace_strict has an undefined or empty value ' 'for param var2', six.text_type(ex)) snippet['str_replace_strict']['allow_empty_param_val'] = True self.assertIn('Template foo string ', self.resolve(snippet, tmpl))

commit_message:
Bring back signal-related tests

Reverts I90e1d26a67a349f897d895f750d8e57fae98ec1f and
I116a96b20082d1c47068ddc64873200e9ae33a27 .

There have been a few changes that should enable these tests to
succeed on a regular basis, all related to edge cases around updating
a resource's atomic_key and metadata:

Corrected max secs for concurrent trans retries
e37d9fab8fe2e779ae8c0e2311de2601b66c66b6

Don't set metadata for deleted resources
8d7e3e41e8f02726dca33b5ec2f6d5b6b6b07a31

Allow retries when resource acquires lock
2ec2d5a973927f9a2cc2a62f70712afc5cb30f4c

Change-Id: I0fe508cf102bc1041a16c5ce1d9e384ecd591173

commit_message:
Supports string values 'none' and 'auto' for networks

Supports to specify string values 'none' and 'auto' for
networks while creating nova server. auto: automatically
allocate network resources if none are available;
none: do not attach a NIC at all. Nova supports these
string values since api version '2.37'.

Change-Id: If65f193dfdaedec3e549a8bd7b39e5f1c02be658
Blueprint: support-auto-none-special-network
Closes-Bug: #1646360

Enable BGP extension in gate_hook.sh

It will affect other projects to set NETWORK_API_EXTENSIONS
in devstack/settings.

are already cloned.
