commit_message:
Make python entry points accessible from elements

More and more functionality in diskimage-builder is implemented using
python.  Nevertheless until now the entry points defined in setup.cfg
are not usable from within the elements.

This patch creates a temporary dedicated python virtual environment
inside the target.  This can then be used from the elements.

This patch also includes path adaption for dib-block-device: the
configuration and state files are stored in a way, that they can be
accessed also from inside the target.

Change-Id: If9039f09f5c712500bdc7a7e0cd189d5000e763a
Signed-off-by: Andreas Florath <andreas@florath.net>

added_lines: def _load_config(file_name): if not os.path.exists(file_name): logger.debug("Skipping config file [%s] - does not exists", file_name) return None # Check for different types if file_name.endswith(".json"): logger.debug("Using json file [%s]", file_name) logger.debug("Using yaml file [%s]", file_name) with codecs.open(file_name, encoding="utf-8", mode="r") as fd: return yaml.safe_load(fd) logger.debug("Params [%s]", self.params) self.state_dir = self.params['state-dir'] self.state_file_name \ self.config_file_name \ = os.path.join(self.state_dir, self.params['config']) logger.debug("Loading config file [%s]", self.config_file_name) self.config = self._load_config(self.config_file_name) logger.debug("Config [%s]", self.config) logger.debug("Loading state file [%s]", self.state_file_name) self.state = self._load_config(self.state_file_name) """Safe the current state of all the different block device layers""" logger.debug("Write state [%s]", self.state_file_name) with open(self.state_file_name, "w") as fd: with open(os.path.join(self.state_dir, self.params['config']), "rt") as config_fd: logger.debug("Final config [%s]", self.config) with open(self.config_file_name, "wt") as fd: logger.info("Wrote final block device config to [%s]", self.config_file_name)
deleted_lines: def _load_json(file_name): if os.path.exists(file_name): return None logger.debug("Params [%s]" % self.params) self.state_dir = os.path.join( self.params['build-dir'], "states/block-device") self.state_json_file_name \ self.config_json_file_name \ = os.path.join(self.state_dir, "config.json") self.config = self._load_json(self.config_json_file_name) self.state = self._load_json(self.state_json_file_name) logger.debug("Write state [%s]" % self.state_json_file_name) with open(self.state_json_file_name, "w") as fd: with open(self.params['config'], "rt") as config_fd: logger.debug("Final config [%s]" % self.config) with open(self.config_json_file_name, "wt") as fd: logger.info("Wrote final block device config to [%s]" % self.config_json_file_name)

commit_message:
Always pass the public endpoint to the client

Even if Horizon is configured to use internal endpoints for requests
made by its server side to other OpenStack services, the client side
should not be restricted to run only in networks which have access to
the internal endpoints.

Change-Id: Ibdc663a133670e8f07530c0d7c5ed7df2d92b99b
Closes-Bug: #1639080

subject: Add a bootstrap_host_exec CMD
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-09 13:03:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/commit/fe1e37e681f1d76490f21e81220ece8a17378812', 'message': 'Add a bootstrap_host_exec CMD

Adds a simple command line utility that will exist in all TripleO
containers (we may need this in a variety of places) so that we
can quickly figure out whether a command should execute on the
bootstrap node (or not).

For example:
  ./bootstrap_host_exec heat_engine heat-manage db_sync

would only execute the DB sync for heat on the bootstrap node.
Internally the script uses hieradata to determine when to run the
supplied command.

Related-Bug: #1688380
Change-Id: If25f217bbb592edab4e1dde53ca99ed93c0e146c
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-05-09 13:03:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/commit/2a7c9a2d154f1ad37f01b88f1707d927255b9eec', 'message': 'Add a bootstrap_host_exec CMD

Adds a simple command line utility that will exist in all TripleO
containers (we may need this in a variety of places) so that we
can quickly figure out whether a command should execute on the
bootstrap node (or not).

For example:
  ./bootstrap_host_exec heat_engine heat-manage db_sync

would only execute the DB sync for heat on the bootstrap node.
Internally the script uses hieradata to determine when to run the
supplied command.

Related-Bug: #1688380
Change-Id: If25f217bbb592edab4e1dde53ca99ed93c0e146c
'}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2017-05-09 13:07:27.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/commit/525ade3171acbbfa58519609c4bdc51206f7c389', 'message': 'Add a bootstrap_host_exec CMD

Adds a simple command line utility that will exist in all TripleO
containers (we may need this in a variety of places) so that we
can quickly figure out whether a command should execute on the
bootstrap node (or not).

For example:
  ./bootstrap_host_exec heat_engine heat-manage db_sync

would only execute the DB sync for heat on the bootstrap node.
Internally the script uses hieradata to determine when to run the
supplied command.

Also, adds openstack-tripleo-common to the base container image so we
can use it in a variety of container images.

commit_message:
Add a bootstrap_host_exec CMD

Adds a simple command line utility that will exist in all TripleO
containers (we may need this in a variety of places) so that we
can quickly figure out whether a command should execute on the
bootstrap node (or not).

For example:
  ./bootstrap_host_exec heat_engine heat-manage db_sync

would only execute the DB sync for heat on the bootstrap node.
Internally the script uses hieradata to determine when to run the
supplied command.

Also, adds openstack-tripleo-common to the base container image so we
can use it in a variety of container images.

Related-Bug: #1688380
Change-Id: If25f217bbb592edab4e1dde53ca99ed93c0e146c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/61/463561/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash SERVICE_NAME=$1 shift HOSTNAME=$(/bin/hostname -s) SERVICE_NODEID=$(/bin/hiera -c /etc/puppet/hiera.yaml "${SERVICE_NAME}_short_bootstrap_node_name") if [[ "$HOSTNAME" == "$SERVICE_NODEID" ]]; then eval $* else echo "Skipping execution since this is not the bootstrap node for this service." fi

commit_message:
Add Opendaylight ML2 configuration options

Two additional config options, port_binding_controller and
odl_hostconf_uri are added to Opendaylight ML2 config file.
Those settings are required for integrating VPP with Honeycomb
agent support.

Partial-Bug: 1675211

Change-Id: I5004fdeb238dea81bc4f7e9437843a8a080d5b46
Signed-off-by: Feng Pan <fpan@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 5adc803d228a24244e6751672cd41b30bdc8b295)

commit_message:
Handle conflicts for os-assisted-volume-snapshots

Since a guest-assisted disk snapshot is performed on the compute
that the instance is running on, there are only certain states
that the instance can be in to perform this operation. For example,
if the instance is shelved_offloaded then the instance does not
have a host and we can't cast to a compute to perform the snapshot.

Given how unrestrictive this API was before, the only restriction
we place on the state is that the instance does not have a task_state
set. We allow any vm_state for performing the operation as long as
there is a host and no task_state.

As noted in the code, we'd normally return a 409 in this case but
according to our microversion docs [1] that would be a new error
code and require a version bump, so this change just uses 400 and
leaves a TODO to make this 409 in a later mass return code update
microversion.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/api_microversion_dev.html#f1

Change-Id: I1dc54a38f02bb48921bcbc4c2fdcc2c946e783c1
Closes-Bug: #1657585

The previous patch to add support for apache breaks gunicorn. The gunicorn

commit_message:
Fix WSGI script for gunicorn

The previous patch to add support for apache breaks gunicorn. The gunicorn
setup loads the mistral.api.wsgi module and requires the application
variable be assigned. The support for apache make the assumption that the
mistral.api.wsgi be called as a python script. This patch moves the init
function required by apache to a different location.

Change-Id: Ib5af50a55d3f3bb9d0fa0d1ee6b8e7564f909d70
Closes-Bug: #1689943
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/70/463870/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Add retries to the ::pacemaker::stonith property

Let's set a default number of retries also for the stonith
property creation. Just like we do for most of the composable
HA resource creation.

commit_message:
Add ability to write static inventory

In some cases it might be useful to just have a static inventory,
since bigger deployments might take a long time to process each
time. This enables the option --static-inventory to the
tripleo-ansible-inventory script, which does just this.

Conflicts:
	scripts/tripleo-ansible-inventory

Related-Bug: #1689789
Change-Id: I96a6b1bc17035b116a85e4e560452321123551dc
(cherry picked from commit 834d014e8965cc8f0ee2d8822200d6deee397ec1)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-validations refs/changes/24/463924/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from six.moves import configparser cfg.StrOpt('static-inventory', help=('output the active hosts ' 'to a static inventory ' 'file.')), return ret return {}def write_static_inventory(inventory_file_path, inventory): with open(inventory_file_path, 'w') as inventory_file: config = configparser.ConfigParser(allow_no_value=True) for section_name, section in inventory.items(): # NOTE(jaosorior): The section might be a list containing the # explicit list of nodes or a dict with several subsections. So # if it's a list, we process that and continue to the next # section. if isinstance(section, list): config.add_section(section_name) for host in section: config.set(section_name, host) continue if 'hosts' in section: config.add_section(section_name) for host in section['hosts']: config.set(section_name, host) if 'vars' in section: vars_section_name = "%s:%s" % (section_name, 'vars') config.add_section(vars_section_name) for var, value in section['vars'].items(): config.set(vars_section_name, var, value) if 'children' in section: children_section_name = "%s:%s" % (section_name, 'children') config.add_section(children_section_name) for child in section['children']: config.set(children_section_name, child) config.write(inventory_file) inventory_list = inventory.list() if configs.list: print(json.dumps(inventory_list)) elif configs.static_inventory: write_static_inventory(configs.static_inventory, inventory_list) elif configs.host: print(json.dumps(inventory.host()))
deleted_lines: print(json.dumps(ret)) print(json.dumps({})) inventory.list() elif configs.host: inventory.host()

commit_message:
Fix the tox environment used for image building

The "images" environment has sitepackages=True, required by the
Python binding for libguestfs (not on pip).

Also, set the Ubuntu kernel so that it can be read by normal.
This affected (and was fixed) many other users of libguestfs. See:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/759725

Change-Id: Icf21a7ee9b575d832d6be5e662d4cfa7b8933611

commit_message:
WIP Fix idempotency and ordering of db sync

Move db sync tasks from docker_config (all nodes)
to docker_puppet_tasks (primary node, one time only)
in order to address idempotency and race condition issues

Closes-bug: #1677652
Change-Id: Ica08f49b6dfc24c65a282fd9257987b290db3888
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

This will likely be squashed into the previous commit, leaving it like

"ready"

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/95/463695/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: initialize: publish: # Initialise some variables that we will use to limit the # introspection retries. introspection_attempt is partially for # auditing, so you can look at a workflow execution and see how # many attempts were made. The failed_node_count is used to make # sure the number of failing nodes is decreasing on each attempt introspection_attempt: 1 failed_node_count: $.node_uuids.len() # Only retry if there are failed nodes and the failed node count is # decreasing. If it isn't we probably have stuck nodes. - send_message: <% $.failed_introspection.len() = 0 or $.failed_introspection.len() >= $.failed_node_count %> - retry_failed_nodes_start: <% $.failed_introspection.len() > 0 and $.failed_introspection.len() < $.failed_node_count %> # We are about to retry, update the tracking stats. introspection_attempt: <% $.introspection_attempt + 1 %> failed_node_count: <% $.failed_node_count.len() %>

commit_message:
Raise exception when base element does not match

Currently it was giving an error with an assertion of none,
and that was not information. Capturing the asserterror, and
raise a more descriptive message for the end user.

Change-Id: Ic90c5cb5e23d96ad3ed93d273a477c29fb9a8b15

commit_message:
Add size checks when creating partitions

If the image size is lower than the size requested for partitions,
the build process was not failing with an error when packing size.
Add a proper check and raise a proper error when that situation
happens.

Change-Id: Iffeda06322ca8268f7f4c29abdb981e028566718
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/08/444208/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # check if we have enough space to create the partition if part_free < part_size: raise RuntimeError("Cannot create a partition of size " "[%d], with only [%d] of free space" % (part_size, part_free))

added_lines: The following documentation applies to the Pike release. Documentation fromSpecial Notes: STIG Content --------------------------- The RHEL 7 STIG content was first added in the Ocata release using the pre-release STIG content (version 0.2). The Pike release contains the final STIG release content which also included a numbering change from the ``RHEL-xx-xxxxxx`` style to the traditional ``V-xxxxx`` style. The original RHEL 6 STIG content was deprecated in the Ocata release and will be removed in the Queens release (early 2018). The documentation for the RHEL 6 STIG content is still available:Pike ~~~~ * **Status:** Active development *(anticipated release: September 2017)* * `openstack-ansible-security Pike Release Notes`_ .. _openstack-ansible-security Pike Release Notes: http://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/openstack-ansible-security/unreleased.html Ocata ~~~~~ * **Status:** Latest stable release *(released February 2017)* * **Supported Operating Systems:** * Ubuntu 14.04 Trusty *(Deprecated)* * Ubuntu 16.04 Xenial * CentOS 7 * Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 *(partial automated test coverage)* * **Documentation:** * `openstack-ansible-security Ocata Documentation`_.. _openstack-ansible-security Ocata Documentation: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/openstack-ansible-security/ocata/ .. _openstack-ansible-security Ocata Release Notes: http://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/openstack-ansible-security/ocata.html* **Status:** Previous stable release *(released October 2016)*

The original RHEL 6 STIG content is deprecated in the Ocata release and will be removed in the next OpenStack release (Pike). The documentation for the RHEL 6 STIG content is still available:Ocata ~~~~~ * **Status:** Development *(anticipated release: February 2017)*.. _openstack-ansible-security Ocata Release Notes: http://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/openstack-ansible-security/unreleased.html* **Status:** Latest stable release *(released 2016-10-20)* Mitaka ~~~~~~ * **Status:** Stable release *(released 2016-04-01)* * **Supported Operating Systems:** Ubuntu 14.04 Trusty * **Documentation:** * `openstack-ansible-security Mitaka Documentation`_ * `openstack-ansible-security Mitaka Release Notes`_ .. _openstack-ansible-security Mitaka Documentation: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/openstack-ansible-security/mitaka/ .. _openstack-ansible-security Mitaka Release Notes: http://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/openstack-ansible-security/mitaka.html

commit_message:
[BUG] Support globally available kafka binaries

Following change adds capabilities of using
globally accessible kafka binaries
(i.e. /usr/bin or /usr/local/bin) instead of
expecting them to be found in /opt/kafka/bin

Story: 2000992
Task: 4169
Change-Id: I86cceb36ceb8dab0aae56ce29fef1283383ff49b

subject: Fix logic for installing a routing file
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-04 10:39:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_container_create/commit/04b931d854ac0b53401a854a8f3e8d7311827af6', 'message': 'Fix logic for installing a routing file

In Ansible, a "string"|bool jinja2 filter does not result to a true
value as presented below:

~$ ansible localhost -e foo="string" -m debug -a "msg={{foo|bool}}"
localhost | SUCCESS => {
    "msg": false
}

Only a "true" string results in a boolean True value

~$ ansible localhost -e foo="true" -m debug -a "msg={{foo|bool}}"
localhost | SUCCESS => {
    "msg": true
}

as such, the routing files where never installed for the RedHat
distributions. We fix this logic by simply leaving this variable
undefined for the distributions who don't need it.

Change-Id: I0af0ad47487365ad593c5550d2c7e05f650e7174

commit_message:
Fix logic for installing a routing file

In Ansible, a "string"|bool jinja2 filter does not result to a true
value as presented below:

~$ ansible localhost -e foo="string" -m debug -a "msg={{foo|bool}}"
localhost | SUCCESS => {
    "msg": false
}

Only a "true" string results in a boolean True value

~$ ansible localhost -e foo="true" -m debug -a "msg={{foo|bool}}"
localhost | SUCCESS => {
    "msg": true
}

as such, the routing files where never installed for the RedHat
distributions. We fix this logic by simply leaving this variable
undefined for the distributions who don't need it.

Change-Id: I0af0ad47487365ad593c5550d2c7e05f650e7174

subject: Make upgrade steps unconditional to fix broken dependencies
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-09 14:19:34.000000000', 'files': ['puppet/major_upgrade_steps.j2.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/commit/345150c243bc3a9bd1dd183395e7cbb0a3974a4f', 'message': 'Make upgrade steps unconditional to fix broken dependencies

Change I5c8b0c4abfc0607f42fd3f2da9f5ef2702b1bbe1 introduced conditions
to optimize upgrade times and fix related bugs. Unfortunately the
conditional inclusion would have to be paired with support in depends_on
to work as we need. Currently we can hit this bug if the batch upgrade
steps are undefined for some role, but upgrade steps are definied:

The specified reference "ControllerUpgradeBatch_Step2" (in
ControllerUpgradeConfig_Step0) is incorrect.

To fix this we have to make the steps unconditional. This isn't fully
reverting the original change because that change also addressed
ordering issues.

Change-Id: I369591f4757c10142f5b455e64aa778e1a9a5611
Closes-Bug: #1689553
'}]
commit_message:
Make upgrade steps unconditional to fix broken dependencies

Change I5c8b0c4abfc0607f42fd3f2da9f5ef2702b1bbe1 introduced conditions
to optimize upgrade times and fix related bugs. Unfortunately the
conditional inclusion would have to be paired with support in depends_on
to work as we need. Currently we can hit this bug if the batch upgrade
steps are undefined for some role, but upgrade steps are definied:

The specified reference "ControllerUpgradeBatch_Step2" (in
ControllerUpgradeConfig_Step0) is incorrect.

To fix this we have to make the steps unconditional. This isn't fully
reverting the original change because that change also addressed
ordering issues.

Change-Id: I369591f4757c10142f5b455e64aa778e1a9a5611
Closes-Bug: #1689553

subject: Make venv build process idempotent
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-05 17:23:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-repo_build/commit/cce5df71aad3a059b6a53c173c06cddd4510c903', 'message': "[WIP] Make venv build process idempotent

The venv build process currently executes on
every build, destroying all existing venvs for
the distribution/architecture of the repo server
it executes on, then rebuilds them.

It is also terribly difficult to troubleshoot
due to the fact that it is executed in parallel
through a single bash script using backgrounded
processes.

This patch breaks the build process up into two
parts - the per-venv requirement files, and the
per-venv script that builds it.

With this breakdown we're able to do the following:
- Only execute a venv rebuild if the venv
  requirements have changed.
- Only execute a venv rebuild if the indexes
  or venv build execution settings have changed.
- Use the Ansible asynchonous execution to
  execute parallel venv builds.

As a very welcome side-effect, this also means
that the venv build execution provides individual
output for success or failures, making it much
easier to see what went wrong when failing.

Change-Id: I063c3addb6fbabb01d620be33aac2cab29a02750

commit_message:
Make venv build process idempotent

The venv build process currently executes on
every build, destroying all existing venvs for
the distribution/architecture of the repo server
it executes on, then rebuilds them.

It is also terribly difficult to troubleshoot
due to the fact that it is executed in parallel
through a single bash script using backgrounded
processes.

This patch breaks the build process up into two
parts - the per-venv options files, and the
script that uses the options to build the venvs.

With this breakdown we're able to do the following:
- Only execute a venv rebuild if the venv
  options (indexes, requirements) have changed.
- Use the Ansible asynchonous execution to
  execute parallel venv builds.

As a very welcome side-effect, this also means
that the venv build execution provides individual
output for success or failures, making it much
easier to see what went wrong when failing.

As part of the patch, the removal of the *.in,
*.txt and *.html files on each wheel build is
taken out. This is to protect the venv options
files. The removal of those files was unnecessary
anyway as they're templated and therefore replaced
by Ansible if they need to be changed.

Change-Id: I063c3addb6fbabb01d620be33aac2cab29a02750

If the 'project_group' for the role is defined and is populated # then the venv will be built. # filtered_venv_role_python_requirements: |- {%- set filtered_role_list = [] %} {%- for role_name, role_data in local_packages.results.0.item.role_requirements.items() %} {%- if ("os_" in role_name) %} {%- set project_group = role_data['project_group'] %} {%- if (not repo_build_venv_selective | bool) or ((groups[project_group] is defined) and (groups[project_group] | length > 0)) %} {%- set _ = filtered_role_list.append({'role_name': role_name, 'role_data': role_data}) %} {%- endif %} {%- endif %} {%- endfor %} {{- filtered_role_list }}

" method = getattr(BlockDevice, attr, None) # The first line is the line that is used phase_doc += " " + method.__doc__.split("
")[0] + "
" return phase_doc def main(): logging_config.setup() logger = logging.getLogger(__name__) phase_doc = generate_phase_doc() parser = argparse.ArgumentParser( formatter_class=argparse.RawDescriptionHelpFormatter, description="Create block device layer", epilog="Available phases:

commit_message:
ScaleIO 1.32 deprecation notice

ScaleIO 1.32 is coming to EOL within Dell EMC. We will deprecate
support in Pike and remove support in a future release

Change-Id: Id3aa5163319b46b21ee5dcecb8559f8498d1f67e

commit_message:
Prevent a bond for unrequired re-assembles

* Assemble bond members under bond in UP state
* FIX lost bridge parameter
* FIX lost 'use_carrier' bond property
* waiting for bond UP after slaves added
* additional flush IP addresses from slave while bond assemble

Change-Id: I568d852e65dc5d5c246e11deb0740f4a608f5ecc
Closes-bug: #1658981
Related-bug: #1657750
(cherry picked from commit 6fde41c44af5ce785053fdf40eddad65a1a1bff4)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/73/430173/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: runtime_slave_ports = self.class.get_sys_class("#{bond_prop_dir}/bonding/slaves", true) bond_is_up = !self.class.get_iface_state(@resource[:bond]).nil? if need_reassembling and !runtime_slave_ports.empty? if need_reassembling and !runtime_slave_ports.empty? self.class.interface_up(@resource[:bond]) # set interface state to UP if !bond_is_up self.class.interface_up(@resource[:bond]) bond_is_up = true end # Change list of slaves if @property_flush.has_key? :slaves if @property_flush[:slaves].nil? or @property_flush[:slaves] == :absent debug("Remove all slave ports from bond '#{@resource[:bond]}'") rm_slave_list = runtime_slave_ports else rm_slave_list = runtime_slave_ports - @property_flush[:slaves] if !rm_slave_list.empty? debug("Remove '#{rm_slave_list.join(',')}' ports from bond '#{@resource[:bond]}'") rm_slave_list.each do |slave| self.class.interface_down(slave) # need by kernel requirements by design. undocumented :( self.class.set_sys_class("#{bond_prop_dir}/bonding/slaves", "-#{slave}") end end # add interfaces to bond add_slave_list = @property_flush[:slaves] - runtime_slave_ports if !add_slave_list.empty? debug("Add '#{add_slave_list.join(',')}' ports to bond '#{@resource[:bond]}'") add_slave_list.each do |slave| debug("Add interface '#{slave}' to bond '#{@resource[:bond]}'") self.class.interface_down(slave) # need by kernel requirements by design. undocumented :( self.class.iproute("addr flush dev #{slave}") self.class.set_sys_class("#{bond_prop_dir}/bonding/slaves", "+#{slave}") self.class.interface_up(slave) end end end if bond_is_up # waiting for bond became UP wait_time = @resource[:bond_properties][:updelay].to_i/1000 || 60.0 wait_step = 0.5 while !self.class.get_iface_state(@resource[:bond]) and wait_time>0 do debug("Waiting for bond '#{@resource[:bond]}' interface UP (#{wait_time})") sleep(wait_step) wait_time -= wait_step end end end # Make bond a member of bridge

:slaves runtime_slave_ports = self.class.get_sys_class("/sys/class/net/#{@resource[:bond]}/bonding/slaves", true) if @property_flush[:slaves].nil? or @property_flush[:slaves] == :absent debug("Remove all slave ports from bond '#{@resource[:bond]}'") rm_slave_list = runtime_slave_ports else rm_slave_list = runtime_slave_ports - @property_flush[:slaves] if !rm_slave_list.empty? debug("Remove '#{rm_slave_list.join(',')}' ports from bond '#{@resource[:bond]}'") rm_slave_list.each do |slave| self.class.interface_down(slave) # need by kernel requirements by design. undocumented :( self.class.set_sys_class("#{bond_prop_dir}/bonding/slaves", "-#{slave}") end end # add interfaces to bond add_slave_list = @property_flush[:slaves] - runtime_slave_ports if !add_slave_list.empty? debug("Add '#{add_slave_list.join(',')}' ports to bond '#{@resource[:bond]}'") add_slave_list.each do |slave| debug("Add interface '#{slave}' to bond '#{@resource[:bond]}'") self.class.interface_down(slave) # need by kernel requirements by design. undocumented :( self.class.set_sys_class("#{bond_prop_dir}/bonding/slaves", "+#{slave}") self.class.interface_up(slave) end end end end # change bond_properties bond_is_up = !self.class.get_iface_state(@resource[:bond]).nil? if need_reassembling runtime_slave_ports = self.class.get_sys_class("#{bond_prop_dir}/bonding/slaves", true) if need_reassembling self.class.interface_up(@resource[:bond]) if !bond_is_up bond_is_up = !self.class.get_iface_state(@resource[:bond]).nil? if bond_is_up self.class.interface_down(@resource[:bond], true) bond_is_up = false end self.class.interface_up(@resource[:bond]) if !bond_is_up

commit_message:
Update reno for new ilo hardware type

This updates the release note for the new 'ilo' hardware type
to mention that it also supports 'iscsi' deploy interface.

The separate release note about ilo supporting iscsi deploy interface
is removed.

This is all going into the same release, and it is confusing to have
two separate release notes about the ilo hardware type.

Change-Id: I4087d7f805dc7710b554c102f428b92cead1ebf9
Related-Bug: #1689274

commit_message:
Fix change API volume create message

The API would log that a volume was created successfully
after successfully sending the async create request. This
patch updates the log message to more accurately state the
request was successfully sent.

Change-Id: I827c54c4ef4d7ad88722782482a39b4f29e322c9
Closes-Bug: #1678034

commit_message:
Create Upstart-compatible state files for each interface

created by l23network in runtime.
This functionality required for correct 'ifdown' command work
first time without ifup (interface created by l23network runtime).

Change-Id: I05aecf2a69158f15eac636e33cedbdfbe817adc0
Closes-bug: #1674430

commit_message:
Fix OVS-related issues with underlay networking

* more intelligent calculation of default port provider
* additional check of patchcord existing in the bridge

OVS provider should be used for fake (OVS) ports, inserted
into OVS bridge. OVS provider should be used for inserting
native linux interface into OVS bridge.

But if we try to add native linux subinterface into
OVS bridge we should use lnx provider for creating
such port correctly.

Change-Id: Ib76b3340eca1ea22095da1cfffe7c224a139fb71
Closes-bug: #1682835

subject: Clone projects if they aren't cloned by ZUUL
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-03-24 10:44:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart-extras/commit/4c12f7db9c178ef2bebaff415a4008fa12f09295', 'message': "Clone projects if they aren't cloned by ZUUL

When we build projects in ZUUL_CHANGES we usually have them
cloned by infra with zuul-cloner in /opt/stack/new with all
required patches, so we just copy them and build. But sometimes
we need to build dependencies in projects that are not in PROJECTS
and not cloned, like heat, glance, etc. This commit supports
cloning and patching of projects that are not cloned by ZUUL
initially.
It was partially implemented in tripleo.sh so we close the gap.

commit_message:
Clone projects if they aren't cloned by ZUUL

When we build projects in ZUUL_CHANGES we usually have them
cloned by infra with zuul-cloner in /opt/stack/new with all
required patches, so we just copy them and build. But sometimes
we need to build dependencies in projects that are not in PROJECTS
and not cloned, like heat, glance, etc. This commit supports
cloning and patching of projects that are not cloned by ZUUL
initially.
It was partially implemented in tripleo.sh so we close the gap.

Close-Bug: #1675380
Change-Id: Icf1af819a07d47eaad185b02795bc68de9cc8e32

commit_message:
Fix for lookup and get_url occuring in different places

We use an SSH bastion host which we do our deployment through. The
deployment host doesn't have direct access to the same network as the
host. As a result the venv local checksum lookup fails.

I have described this here:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1689283

This is a simple fix for this problem, assuming everything is good it
will need repeating in multiple places in the code base.

Change-Id: I02c77c3f3416955c1e2a15a2716f786e7cf818bf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_gnocchi refs/changes/15/463715/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - name: Retrieve checksum for venv download uri: url: "{{ gnocchi_venv_download_url | replace('tgz', 'checksum') }}" return_content: yes register: gnocchi_venv_checksum when: gnocchi_venv_download | bool checksum: "sha1:{{ gnocchi_venv_checksum.content | trim }}"

commit_message:
Fix for lookup and get_url occuring in different places

We use an SSH bastion host which we do our deployment through. The
deployment host doesn't have direct access to the same network as the
host. As a result the venv local checksum lookup fails.

I have described this here:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1689283

This is a simple fix for this problem, assuming everything is good it
will need repeating in multiple places in the code base.

Change-Id: Ib0693f6ff28e2f9e9b2befbd1abc05945a7b6d61

commit_message:
Take --params from environment

DIB_BLOCK_DEVICE_PARAMS_YAML should be exported, and the
dib-block-device will take this as the value of --params.  Remove this
to simplify the command-line

Change-Id: I6764ed223ecd36f9d24e19f164b6a927380b410f

commit_message:
Client support for service delete

This patch adds support for service delete in client.

Change-Id: I2d85c9dc2dcba45cae1efdecf247967ea57556dc
Partially-Implements: blueprint enhance-service-api
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-zunclient refs/changes/92/459992/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def delete(self, host, binary): """Delete a service.""" return self._delete(self._path(), qparams={'host': host, 'binary': binary})

commit_message:
K8s Services support: LoadBalancerHandler

This patch implements LoadBalancerHandler that handles K8s Endpoints
events and tracks changes in LBaaSServiceSpec to update Neutron LBaaS
accordingly and to reflect its' actual state in LBaaSState.

Change-Id: I718daf6d3def981c1bde5ca9831f955766935fbd
Partially-Implements: blueprint kuryr-k8s-integration

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2016 Mirantis, Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import datetime import six from neutronclient.common import exceptions as n_exc from oslo_log import log as logging from oslo_serialization import jsonutils from oslo_utils import timeutils from kuryr.lib._i18n import _LE from kuryr_kubernetes import clients from kuryr_kubernetes import constants as const from kuryr_kubernetes import events from kuryr_kubernetes import exceptions as exc LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class LBaaSServiceProcessor(events.K8sObjectEventProcessor): OBJECT_KIND = 'Service' TTL = 300 def __init__(self, context): self._neutron = clients.get_neutron_client() self._kubernetes = clients.get_kubernetes_client() self._ctx = context def on_present(self, svc_event): try: service_type = svc_event.obj['spec']['type'] if service_type != const.CLUSTER_IP_SERVICE_TYPE: return except KeyError: return vip_subnet = self._ctx[const.SERVICE_SUBNET( namespace=svc_event.obj_namespace)] lb = self._lb_request(svc_event, vip_subnet) if not lb: return if 'verified_at' not in lb: lb = self._get_or_create_lb(lb) else: return self._ensure_annotations(svc_event, { const.LOADBALANCER_ANNOTATION: lb}) if lb['operating_status'] != const.LOADBALANCER_ONLINE: raise exc.IncompleteState(_LE( "LoadBalancer %s is %s but expected %s" % ( lb['id'], lb['operating_status'], const.LOADBALANCER_ONLINE))) else: lb['verified_at'] = datetime.datetime.utcnow().isoformat() self._ensure_annotations(svc_event, { const.LOADBALANCER_ANNOTATION: lb}) def on_deleted(self, svc_event): pass def _lb_request(self, svc_event, vip_subnet): try: cluster_ip = svc_event.obj['spec']['clusterIP'] except KeyError: return try: lb = jsonutils.loads(svc_event.obj_annotations[ const.LOADBALANCER_ANNOTATION]) if timeutils.is_older_than(lb['verified_at'], self.TTL): del lb['verified_at'] except KeyError: lb = { 'name': 'svc:%s:%s' % (svc_event.obj_namespace, svc_event.obj_name), 'vip_address': cluster_ip, 'vip_subnet_id': vip_subnet['id'], 'tenant_id': vip_subnet['tenant_id'] } return lb def _find_lb(self, lb): params = {k: lb[k] for k in ['vip_address', 'vip_subnet_id', 'tenant_id']} return self._neutron.list_loadbalancers(**params)['loadbalancers'] def _get_or_create_lb(self, lb): lb_list = self._find_lb(lb) if len(lb_list) > 1: raise exc.InvalidState(_LE("Non-unique LoadBalancer for %s" % lb)) if lb_list: return lb_list[0] try: lb_resp = self._neutron.create_loadbalancer({'loadbalancer': lb}) LOG.debug("%r created LoadBalancer %s" % (self, lb_resp)) return lb_resp['loadbalancer'] except n_exc.IpAddressInUseClient: raise exc.IncompleteState(_LE( "LoadBalancer already created for %s" % lb)) def _delete_lb(self, lb): try: self._neutron.delete_loadbalancer(lb['id']) LOG.debug("%r deleted LoadBalancer %s" % (self, lb)) except n_exc.NotFound: pass def _ensure_annotations(self, event, values, link=None): if link is None: link = event.obj_link values = {key: value for key, value in ( (k, jsonutils.dumps(v, sort_keys=True)) for k, v in six.iteritems(values) ) if value != event.obj_annotations.get(key)} if not values: return try: event.obj_annotations = self._kubernetes.annotate(link, values) except exc.K8sClientException as ex: raise exc.IncompleteState(ex)

commit_message:
Catch exception during calling os.chmod in set_configs.py

set_perms may fail in some case, but it is not critical. Just leave a
warning rather than exit.

Change-Id: I757c7b60611fb6c0547bd1b26ec8a8af03684e5f
Closes-Bug: 1689454

commit_message:
Using fixtures instead of deprecated mockpatch module

This module mockpatch of oslotest[1] is deprecated since version 1.13
and may be removed in version 2.0. Use fixtures.Mock* classes instead[2]

[1]OpenStack Testing Framework and Utilities
[2]https://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslotest/api/oslotest.mockpatch.html#module-oslotest.mockpatch

Change-Id: I4aa3c88dd4bd0161704f1776a4900562c6aa2329

commit_message:
Update file and directory permissions

Currently the clouds.yaml directory permissions are hardcoded and
missing the execute bit. When using this role with a default location in
/etc/openstack, normal system users are not able to read the
configuration file.

This commit adds variable overrides for the file and directory
permissions, as well as correcting the directory permissions.

Change-Id: I2380030235d455ff4dd0ea7658c7146ece60db81
Closes-Bug: #1689837

commit_message:
Create BlockDeviceCmd object

This creates a BlockDeviceCmd object to hold the main() function.
This doesn't really do anything different right now, but sets a base
for using argparse subparsers to handle the command-line

Change-Id: I4acf95ff4d554a3b4e7e2244ab1706631b98458f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/38/461638/11 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
class BlockDeviceCmd(object): def generate_phase_doc(self): phase_doc = "" bdattrs = dir(BlockDevice) for attr in bdattrs: if attr.startswith("cmd_"): phase_doc += " '" + attr[4:] + "'
" method = getattr(BlockDevice, attr, None) # The first line is the line that is used phase_doc += " " + method.__doc__.split("
")[0] + "
" return phase_doc def main(self): logging_config.setup() logger = logging.getLogger(__name__) phase_doc = self.generate_phase_doc() parser = argparse.ArgumentParser( formatter_class=argparse.RawDescriptionHelpFormatter, description="Create block device layer", epilog="Available phases:
" + phase_doc) parser.add_argument('--phase', required=True, help="phase to execute") parser.add_argument('--params', required=False, help="YAML file containing parameters for " "block-device handling. Default is " "DIB_BLOCK_DEVICE_PARAMS_YAML") parser.add_argument('--symbol', required=False, help="symbol to query for getval") args = parser.parse_args() # Find, open and parse the parameters file if not args.params: if 'DIB_BLOCK_DEVICE_PARAMS_YAML' in os.environ: param_file = os.environ['DIB_BLOCK_DEVICE_PARAMS_YAML'] else: parser.error( "DIB_BLOCK_DEVICE_PARAMS_YAML or --params not set") else: param_file = args.params logger.info("params [%s]" % param_file) try: with open(param_file) as f: params = yaml.safe_load(f) except Exception: logger.exception("Failed to open parameter YAML") sys.exit(1) logger.info("phase [%s]" % args.phase) if args.symbol: logger.info("symbol [%s]" % args.symbol) bd = BlockDevice(params, args) # Check if the method is available method = getattr(bd, "cmd_" + args.phase, None) if callable(method): # If so: call it. return method() else: logger.error("phase [%s] does not exists" % args.phase) return 1 bdc = BlockDeviceCmd() return bdc.main() sys.exit(main())

" method = getattr(BlockDevice, attr, None) # The first line is the line that is used phase_doc += " " + method.__doc__.split("
")[0] + "
" return phase_doc logging_config.setup() logger = logging.getLogger(__name__) phase_doc = generate_phase_doc() parser = argparse.ArgumentParser( formatter_class=argparse.RawDescriptionHelpFormatter, description="Create block device layer", epilog="Available phases:
" + phase_doc) parser.add_argument('--phase', required=True, help="phase to execute") parser.add_argument('--params', required=False, help="YAML file containing parameters for block-device" "handling. Default is DIB_BLOCK_DEVICE_PARAMS_YAML") parser.add_argument('--symbol', required=False, help="symbol to query for getval") args = parser.parse_args() # Find, open and parse the parameters file if not args.params: if 'DIB_BLOCK_DEVICE_PARAMS_YAML' in os.environ: param_file = os.environ['DIB_BLOCK_DEVICE_PARAMS_YAML'] else: parser.error("DIB_BLOCK_DEVICE_PARAMS_YAML or --params not set") else: param_file = args.params logger.info("params [%s]" % param_file) try: with open(param_file) as f: params = yaml.safe_load(f) except Exception: logger.exception("Failed to open parameter YAML") sys.exit(1) logger.info("phase [%s]" % args.phase) if args.symbol: logger.info("symbol [%s]" % args.symbol) bd = BlockDevice(params, args) # Check if the method is available method = getattr(bd, "cmd_" + args.phase, None) if callable(method): # If so: call it. return method() else: logger.error("phase [%s] does not exists" % args.phase) return 1 return 0 main()

commit_message:
Move YAML parsing into cmd.py; default to env

This moves the YAML parameter parsing into the command-line driver.
It makes the argument optional so it can be taken from the environment
variable directly.  The parsed YAML is passed to the BlockDevice
object.

Change-Id: I6fa5e5b7d1fccfc7cf47d6e4a1fa6e560734680d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/36/461636/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __init__(self, params, args): """Create BlockDevice object Arguments: :param params: YAML file from --params :param args: arguments from cmd argparse """ self.params = params
deleted_lines: def __init__(self, args): logger.debug("Param file [%s]" % args.params) with open(self.args.params) as param_fd: self.params = yaml.safe_load(param_fd)

commit_message:
Add ability to write static inventory

In some cases it might be useful to just have a static inventory,
since bigger deployments might take a long time to process each
time. This enables the option --static-inventory to the
tripleo-ansible-inventory script, which does just this.

Related-Bug: #1689789
Change-Id: I96a6b1bc17035b116a85e4e560452321123551dc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-validations refs/changes/13/463913/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from six.moves import configparser cfg.StrOpt('static-inventory', help=('output the active hosts ' 'to a static inventory ' 'file.')),def write_static_inventory(inventory_file_path, inventory): with open(inventory_file_path, 'w') as inventory_file: config = configparser.ConfigParser(allow_no_value=True) for section_name, section in inventory.items(): if 'hosts' in section: config.add_section(section_name) for host in section['hosts']: config.set(section_name, host) if 'vars' in section: vars_section_name = "%s:%s" % (section_name, 'vars') config.add_section(vars_section_name) for var, value in section['vars'].items(): config.set(vars_section_name, var, value) if 'children' in section: children_section_name = "%s:%s" % (section_name, 'children') config.add_section(children_section_name) for child in section['children']: config.set(children_section_name, child) config.write(inventory_file) if configs.list or configs.static_inventory: try: inventory_list = inventory.list() if configs.list: print(json.dumps(inventory_list)) elif configs.static_inventory: write_static_inventory(configs.static_inventory, inventory_list)

commit_message:
Pass printing responsibility to dynamic inventory script

The class object now just returns the dict, and the responsibility
of printing the json object is now part of the dynamic inventory
script. This separation was done so in a further commit, more options
can be passed to this script.

Related-Bug: #1689789
Change-Id: I51dfd8618b88bcd2d28dbc799dbb4820c6055705

subject: cname_lookup nameserver override follow-up
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-10 14:26:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/92e1eed3429e4fc5c7637ca482ea2873d51a12c1', 'message': 'cname_lookup nameserver override follow-up

- Allow port overrides
- Change the required IPv6 format from addresses like `::1` to ones like
  `[::1]`, so we can do port overrides like `[::1]:5354`
- Add tests for IPv6
- Add tests for successfully setting a list of nameservers

commit_message:
cname_lookup nameserver override follow-up

- Allow port overrides
- Change the required IPv6 format from addresses like `::1` to ones like
  `[::1]`, so we can do port overrides like `[::1]:5354`
- Add tests for IPv6
- Add tests for successfully setting a list of nameservers
- Stop instatiating a new resolver on every lookup

Change-Id: I7536ac2b05a4fb532f129579333f4c1fc5d09fd1
Related-Change: I34219e6ab7e45678c1a80ff76a1ac0730c64ddde
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/70/463770/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: list_from_csv, parse_socket_string, register_swift_info def lookup_cname(domain, resolver): # pragma: no cover nameservers = list_from_csv(conf.get('nameservers')) try: for i, server in enumerate(nameservers): ip_or_host, port = nameservers[i] = \ parse_socket_string(server, None) if not is_valid_ip(ip_or_host): raise ValueError if port is not None: int(port) except ValueError: nameservers = [] self.resolver = dns.resolver.Resolver() if nameservers: self.resolver.nameservers = [ip for ip, port in nameservers] self.resolver.nameserver_ports = { ip: int(port) for ip, port in nameservers if port is not None} self.resolver)
deleted_lines: list_from_csv, register_swift_info def lookup_cname(domain, nameservers): # pragma: no cover resolver = dns.resolver.Resolver() if nameservers: resolver.nameservers = nameservers self.nameservers = list_from_csv(conf.get('nameservers')) if self.nameservers and not all([is_valid_ip(ns) for ns in self.nameservers]): self.nameservers = [] self.nameservers)

'}, {'number': 6, 'created': '2017-03-08 20:49:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi/commit/e2e0376b6fe3f9cda879c93c8161cc8a048001fa', 'message': "push incoming into different sacks

having everything in one giant folder/bucket/conatiner/object is bad
because:
- does not allow for good distribution of backend driver.
- makes it hella hard to cleanly split work across multiple metricd
- starves metrics from being processed.

this creates 4096 sacks to distributes them across agents. everything
else pretty much works the same. the agent will loop through all its
sacks based on processing_interval.

the number of sacks is constant because it's not safe without more
code which hasn't been agreed upon.

i used sacks to avoid not naming same as driver paradigms.

Change-Id: Icc32d918fe55416385122470c47d60ddbb30dd34

"}, {'number': 28, 'created': '2017-03-30 21:08:06.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi/commit/acf510e4d66780532ff3a54912266888445993f2', 'message': "push incoming into different sacks

having everything in one giant folder/bucket/container/object is bad
because:
- does not allow for good distribution of backend driver.
- makes it hella hard to cleanly split work across multiple metricd
- starves metrics from being processed.

this creates 32 sacks to distributes them across agents. this also
drops the scheduling process and lets each processing worker register
to group and grab its own sacks to process.

NOTE:
- s3 is set to 4 buckets because it seems to have a bunch of restrictions.

the number of sacks is constant because it's not safe without more
code which hasn't been agreed upon.

i used sacks to avoid not naming same as driver paradigms.

Closes-Bug: #1629420
Closes-Bug: #1623263
Change-Id: Icc32d918fe55416385122470c47d60ddbb30dd34
"}, {'number': 29, 'created': '2017-03-30 21:10:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/gnocchi/commit/1e38946fb15874914eef8942dce509da4bdd31a4', 'message': "push incoming into different sacks

having everything in one giant folder/bucket/container/object is bad
because:
- does not allow for good distribution of backend driver.
- makes it hella hard to cleanly split work across multiple metricd
- starves metrics from being processed.

this creates 32 sacks to distributes them across agents. this also
drops the scheduling process and lets each processing worker register
to group and grab its own sacks to process.

NOTE:
- s3 is set to 4 buckets because it seems to have a bunch of restrictions.

the number of sacks is constant because it's not safe without more
code which hasn't been agreed upon.

i used sacks to avoid not naming same as driver paradigms.

Closes-Bug: #1629420
Closes-Bug: #1623263
Change-Id: Icc32d918fe55416385122470c47d60ddbb30dd34

commit_message:
push incoming into different sacks

having everything in one giant folder/bucket/container/object is bad
because:
- does not allow for good distribution of backend driver.
- makes it hella hard to cleanly split work across multiple metricd
- starves metrics from being processed.

we used "sacks" to avoid naming same as driver paradigms.

driver implementation will be done individually so this does nothing but
pretend to lock multiple buckets when it's actually just one.

Related-Bug: #1629420
Related-Bug: #1623263
Related-Bug: #1620674
Change-Id: Icc32d918fe55416385122470c47d60ddbb30dd34

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. # """add bucket info Revision ID: 9420813ce89d Revises: 1e1a63d3d186 Create Date: 2017-03-03 16:13:54.106040 """ from alembic import op import sqlalchemy as sa # revision identifiers, used by Alembic. revision = '9420813ce89d' down_revision = '1e1a63d3d186' branch_labels = None depends_on = None def upgrade(): op.add_column('metric', sa.Column('bucket', sa.Integer, nullable=True)) metric = sa.Table('metric', sa.MetaData(), sa.Column('bucket', sa.Integer)) op.execute(metric.update().values(bucket=0)) op.alter_column('metric', 'bucket', nullable=False, existing_nullable=True) op.create_table('storage_state', sa.Column('buckets', sa.Integer, nullable=False)) state = sa.Table('storage_state', sa.MetaData(), sa.Column('buckets', sa.Integer)) op.execute(state.insert().values(buckets=1))

subject: oslo_service.periodic_task KeyError: 'NanoCpus'

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-05-09 12:10:08.000000000', 'files': ['zun/container/docker/driver.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/zun/commit/cc9e19d2486e78447a9f3267fb5f0d75a345ee8f', 'message': "oslo_service.periodic_task KeyError: 'NanoCpus'

commit_message:
oslo_service.periodic_task KeyError: 'NanoCpus'

Thers is no NanoCpus field before docker engine API (v1.25)

Change-Id: If7c09bbb060ca1449056c8122aa92a2b0a2bb619

commit_message:
Fix gate failures

This commit fixes the issue with gate.
Still issues pending with usage of v2. It comments the following
tests to unblock the gate.

TODO(ramineni): Fix keystonev2 auth, and replace keystone v2 tests with v3
                Fix HA tests to use v3 clients (bug:1689220)

Closes-Bug:#1689221
Change-Id: I66e9ddb4ae6d3819f0b47fab220607cfe8446171

commit_message:
Fix arguments for OS::Mistral::CronTrigger create

In python-mistralclient, the `workflow_name` argument was renamed to
`workflow_identifier` in version 2.0.0, breaking this resource type. Ensure
that this works with all client versions by passing the first two arguments
as positional rather than keyword args.

Change-Id: Ibbed3af468bbc0d68995495095b6cd340c1ea427
Closes-Bug: #1557575
(cherry picked from commit f682e7afed80ea0bcd19f42644a64a0b750f3eac)

deleted_lines: args = self.client.cron_triggers.create.call_args[1] self.assertEqual('* * 0 * *', args['pattern']) self.assertEqual('get_first_glance_image', args['workflow_name']) self.assertEqual({}, args['workflow_input']) self.assertEqual('2015-04-08 06:20', args['first_time']) self.assertEqual(3, args['count'])

commit_message:
Driver for cinder v2

This adds a driver for cinder v2. We will use this driver for checking
volumes.

Change-Id: I57dc961e4d127c92cd87a529d7ac16e76b1e6a92
Signed-off-by: Yuanbin.Chen <cybing4@gmail.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/67/463467/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock from senlin.drivers.openstack import cinder_v2 from senlin.drivers.openstack import sdk from senlin.tests.unit.common import base from senlin.tests.unit.common import utils @mock.patch.object(sdk, 'create_connection') class TestCinderV2(base.SenlinTestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestCinderV2, self).setUp() self.ctx = utils.dummy_context() self.conn_params = self.ctx.to_dict() self.fake_conn = mock.Mock() self.volume = self.fake_conn.block_store def test_init(self, mock_create): mock_create.return_value = self.fake_conn vo = cinder_v2.CinderClient(self.conn_params) self.assertEqual(self.fake_conn, vo.conn) mock_create.assert_called_once_with(self.conn_params) def test_volume_get(self, mock_create): mock_create.return_value = self.fake_conn vo = cinder_v2.CinderClient(self.conn_params) res = vo.volume_get('foo') expected = self.volume.get_volume.return_value self.assertEqual(expected, res) self.volume.get_volume.assert_called_once_with('foo')

commit_message:
Verify scheduler_interval's format while creating jobs.

Django will return an submit error if the format is
not correct, which can be very confused. It is better
to return an field error to user.

Change-Id: I9dc3736960c7e91a8ea61f85adb3a1d2a2a4ef83
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/freezer-web-ui refs/changes/22/441822/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import reSCHEDULE_INTERVAL_REGEX = "^(continuous|(\d+ +(weeks|days|hours|minutes|seconds)))$" self._check_interval(cleaned_data) def _check_interval(self, cleaned_data): pattern = re.compile(SCHEDULE_INTERVAL_REGEX) if cleaned_data.get('schedule_interval') and not \ pattern.match(cleaned_data.get('schedule_interval')): msg = _("The format of interval is not correct." ) self._errors['schedule_interval'] = self.error_class([msg])

commit_message:
No images available when deploying a k8s cluster

After import the k8s app and image, and setting the metedata
"linux.kubernetes" for teh image, then chicking "Quick deploy" to
deploy the k8s cluster. But I get the error "No images available".

Change-Id: I5637bdee50221d5f8fc65e5948d6a8990afdaacd
Closes-Bug: #1664486

Change-Id: Iee4fa41ffaf243e4728bf3a5eeec5c8fa8d2dadc
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2017-05-09 05:34:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/b5fdb90e9745d14855089c303d0c6c44e58ce8f8', 'message': 'exec_sudo: command should be "str"

To avoid any confusion, commands passed to exec_sudo() should be a
list of "str"s.

I think the problems here started with "str(uuid.uuid4()).encode()"
which converted "uuid" to bytes, which was then passed as a
command-line argument and failed when we try to print the join()ed
string (I don't think Popen cares).

We seem to have then patched up various places ... which is exactly
the confusion to avoid.  If we have un-encoded data (from a socket
call, or subprocess call, etc) we should convert it when we process it
at the "point of entry" so a) we have a chance of getting the encoding
right and b) internally we're all str.

This also adds a debug trace of the returned output.

Change-Id: Iee4fa41ffaf243e4728bf3a5eeec5c8fa8d2dadc
'}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2017-05-09 06:25:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/0f9813e9b3a7bb8f12a5030e2c67af4cde5f612d', 'message': 'exec_sudo: command should be "str"

the confusion to avoid.  If we have un-encoded data (from a socket
call, or subprocess call, etc) we should convert it when we process it
at the "point of entry" so a) we have a chance of getting the encoding
right and b) internally we're all str.

This also adds a debug trace of the returned output.

commit_message:
exec_sudo: check cmd for str, log output and raise exception

To avoid any confusion, commands passed to exec_sudo() should be a
list of "str"s.  Log a message if we see unicode issues.

This also adds a debug trace of all output.  stderr is captured.

This is modified to raise CalledProcessError on failure, like
check_call().  Calls that are ok to fail will need to explicitly catch
and ignore this.

The two calls that we expect to fail are wrapped

We wish to try rolling back if one of these command raises an
exception.  Modify the create handler to initiate rollback on all
exceptions.

Change-Id: Iee4fa41ffaf243e4728bf3a5eeec5c8fa8d2dadc

commit_message:
add configuration instructions from admin guide and dev docs

- move cinder and keystone configuration instructions from admin
guide to install guide so we have all meter enabling steps in
same place.
- move heat and neutron config to install guide.

Change-Id: Ibc8096e3fb6c95886c3bddafb927600fe506415d
(cherry picked from commit 9105e194c73628202715e9d24f59a69a5392a71e)

added_lines: Enable Orchestration service meters for Red Hat Enterprise Linux and CentOS ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Telemetry uses notifications to collect Orchestration service meters. Perform these steps on the controller node. Configure the Orchestration service to use Telemetry ---------------------------------------------------- * Edit the ``/etc/heat/heat.conf`` and complete the following actions: * In the ``[oslo_messaging_notifications]`` sections, enable notifications: .. code-block:: ini [oslo_messaging_notifications] ... driver = messagingv2 Finalize installation --------------------- * Restart the Orchestration service: .. code-block:: console # systemctl restart openstack-heat-api.service \ openstack-heat-api-cfn.service openstack-heat-engine.service

subject: Properly allow Ironic headers in REST API
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-04-26 23:54:07.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/e607eefd0b1bcc86022efd23eebabde4e67ea516', 'message': 'Properly allow Ironic headers in REST API

In 7fd26bf8031041a0e6df261c71101e29e8bf9610 ("Fix usage of various deprecated
methods", 2017-02-27), the `app.set_latent()` call was replaced with
`cors_middleware.set_defaults()`.  While the mentioned deprecation warning
suggests that the `set_defaults()` function replaces the former `set_latent()`,
they accomplish the same goal but with a different implementation.

`set_defaults()` allows you to specify certain ready-made configration options
in case the developer doesn't provide them in ironic.conf.  However,
`set_latent()` provides configuration that is additive in nature.  This means
that values that have been set with `set_defaults()` will be overridden by
values in ironic.conf, while those set by `set_latent()` will not.

This becomes a problem in the case of the Ironic-specific headers, e.g.
`X-OpenStack-Ironic-API-Version`.  In the Ironic API configuration, we need
explicitely allow these headers in incoming requests.  Otherwise, the request
will be rejected on the grounds that a foreign header is present.  Using
`set_defaults()` to accomplish this doesn't work because those Ironic-specific
headers will be replaced by whatever is set in ironic.conf.

The solution is to add these headers to the `simple_headers` list which is used
as a base when constructing the final list of allowed headers in incoming
OPTIONS requests.  We subclass the real `CORS` class from oslo.middleware and
add the headers to the list.

Change-Id: Ib2b6a11be276220e31d305f4b0a87843d5418958
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2017-04-27 18:45:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/commit/0057f2e567b4a281335d145d7917d807f51f0e85', 'message': 'Properly allow Ironic headers in REST API

In 7fd26bf8031041a0e6df261c71101e29e8bf9610 ("Fix usage of various deprecated
methods", 2017-02-27), the `app.set_latent()` call was replaced with
`cors_middleware.set_defaults()`.  While the mentioned deprecation warning
suggests that the `set_defaults()` function replaces the former `set_latent()`,
they accomplish the same goal but with a different implementation.

`set_defaults()` allows you to specify certain ready-made configration options
in case the developer doesn't provide them in ironic.conf.  However,
`set_latent()` provides configuration that is additive in nature.  This means
that values that have been set with `set_defaults()` will be overridden by
values in ironic.conf, while those set by `set_latent()` will not.

This becomes a problem in the case of the Ironic-specific headers, e.g.
`X-OpenStack-Ironic-API-Version`.  In the Ironic API configuration, we need
explicitely allow these headers in incoming requests.  Otherwise, the request
will be rejected on the grounds that a foreign header is present.  Using
`set_defaults()` to accomplish this doesn't work because those Ironic-specific
headers will be replaced by whatever is set in ironic.conf.

The solution is to add these headers to the `simple_headers` list which is used
as a base when constructing the final list of allowed headers in incoming
OPTIONS requests.  We subclass the real `CORS` class from oslo.middleware and
add the headers to the list.

commit_message:
Properly allow Ironic headers in REST API

In 7fd26bf8031041a0e6df261c71101e29e8bf9610 ("Fix usage of various deprecated
methods", 2017-02-27), the `app.set_latent()` call was replaced with
`cors_middleware.set_defaults()`.  While the mentioned deprecation warning
suggests that the `set_defaults()` function replaces the former `set_latent()`,
they accomplish the same goal but with a different implementation.

`set_defaults()` allows you to specify certain ready-made configration options
in case the developer doesn't provide them in ironic.conf.  However,
`set_latent()` provides configuration that is additive in nature.  This means
that values that have been set with `set_defaults()` will be overridden by
values in ironic.conf, while those set by `set_latent()` will not.

This becomes a problem in the case of the Ironic-specific headers, e.g.
`X-OpenStack-Ironic-API-Version`.  In the Ironic API configuration, we need
explicitely allow these headers in incoming requests.  Otherwise, the request
will be rejected on the grounds that a foreign header is present.  Using
`set_defaults()` to accomplish this doesn't work because those Ironic-specific
headers will be replaced by whatever is set in ironic.conf.

The solution is to add these headers to the `simple_headers` list which is used
as a base when constructing the final list of allowed headers in incoming
OPTIONS requests.  We subclass the real `CORS` class from oslo.middleware and
add the headers to the list.

Change-Id: Ib2b6a11be276220e31d305f4b0a87843d5418958
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/53/460353/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: class IronicCORS(cors_middleware.CORS): """ Ironic-specific CORS class We're adding the Ironic-specific version headers to the list of simple headers in order that a request bearing those headers might be accepted by the Ironic REST API. """ simple_headers = [ 'Accept', 'Accept-Language', 'Content-Type', 'Cache-Control', 'Content-Language', 'Expires', 'Last-Modified', 'Pragma', base.Version.max_string, base.Version.min_string, base.Version.string ] app = IronicCORS(app, CONF)

commit_message:
Fix Cassandra cluster restart

Look the node up by both '127.0.0.1' and the private IP (if not found).

Change-Id: Iddd76e6abc5d4ecc68cbd53c554ea994c51db115
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/16/425916/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if self.client.local_node_is_up(): return rd_instance.ServiceStatuses.RUNNING def node_is_up(self, host_ip): """Test whether the Cassandra node located at the given IP is up. """ for host in self._cluster.metadata.all_hosts(): if host.address == host_ip: return host.is_up return False def local_node_is_up(self): """Test whether Cassandra is up on the localhost. """ return (self.node_is_up('127.0.0.1') or self.node_is_up(netutils.get_my_ipv4()))

commit_message:
Remove the heat tests

This commit removes the heat tests from tempest, we've been pushing for
these to become a plugin for a long time without any progress. In
addition the heat team has no desire to maintain these tests. [1] Since
they're not providing value anymore let's just delete them. Note, the
clients are not removed in this patch because other projects depend on
those and we shouldn't break those users. Ideally those interfaces
should be moved to lib and just left there.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-May/116170.html

Depends-On: I983de842f1bf84a939cbcda6c65185c694a69949
Change-Id: Ifc2cac575919da4e361eaa3234d7e0f3e2f98d21

commit_message:
Add 'iscsi' deploy support for 'ilo' hardware type

The classic iLO driver 'pxe_ilo', uses 'iscsi' deploy method and
there by avoids dependency on Swift Temp URL for glance images.
With no support to 'iscsi' deploy interface, 'ilo' hardware type
do not provide complete compatibility with all classic iLO drivers.

This commit adds support for 'iscsi' deploy interface for 'ilo'
hardware type so that one could compose a driver for a node that
matches any of the classic iLO drivers.

Closes-Bug: #1689274

Change-Id: I6c5f4d68020bcf58b83d74f45bb059f1807a80ee

commit_message:
Cleanup CentOS pkg

Do not insall from EPEL
install postgresql-devel instead of lbpqxx-devel
install qemu-img-ev instead of qemu-img

Change-Id: I9d0574ec2d13adf672f918e8548606557e0fc654
(cherry picked from commit 942ec4d68e18c68e407464ebfe52b55299d7805b)

commit_message:
Update React to 15.5

- Install prop-types library
- Updates react-portal due to react dependency
- Install react-test-renderer instead of react-addons-test-utils

Change-Id: I6f17f97419b3ad3efc2440db1a52fb6719d3eb4a

commit_message:
Fix built repo installation

Built packages should be installed with web-repo in order to be
installed on overcloud.

supported now.

commit_message:
Support dcos installation on centos vm cluster

This patch provides support for installing dcos on centos using magnum.
A new coe type(dcos) is added. This provides support for vm.
Design spec and steps on how to test can be found in
contrib/drivers/dcos_centos_v1/README.md.

Public agent nodes are not supported now.

Co-Authored-By: fengbeihong (fengbeihong@gmail.com)
Co-Authored-By: vmud213 (vinay50muddu@yahoo.com)

Change-Id: I58b378b4bd6df34fd43307e4252cfbbd9bf593d8
Partially-Implements: blueprint mesos-dcos

commit_message:
CalculateAmphoraDelta networks based on vrrp_port

Calculating this based on the vip subnet only works in the specific case
that the vrrp ports are on the vip subnet. This may not always be true,
and depends on the drivers used. Pulling it directly from the vrrp port
should work in *all* cases.

Change-Id: Ic39c223df0af380398073e04fafcf50495e7b94d

commit_message:
Allow specifying empty amp_boot_network_list

Some nova deployments automatically select their networks on boot.
We can allow for this by assuming there will be some default network if
the amp_boot_network_list is empty.

Change-Id: I38ccfb45afb93795860c12efaf5a32f9bd1689fd

commit_message:
Add spec for Zone migration strategy

This spec describes zone migration strategy implementation.

Change-Id: I83c8f3bf1b88828c5e06b16ef0c9c4309f7f319e
Implements:blueprint zone-migration-strategy
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/watcher-specs refs/changes/34/457834/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ======================= Zone migration Strategy ======================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/watcher/+spec/zone-migration-strategy There are thousands of physical servers and storage running various kinds of workloads in the Cloud system. The administrator has to migrate instances and volumes for hardware maintenance once a year. For easy maintenance, hardware are divided into groups, each has the same amount of hardware managed by external CMDB. One physical zone is only for maintenance(Let's say 'Maintenance Zone', 'MZ' for short), other zones are opened in public. (Let's say 'Service Zone', 'SZ' for short). The administrator repeats steps for each SZ: 1) Set MZ into the same availability zone as SZ, set compute nodes into the same aggregate as SZ 2) Disable openstack services on each compute/storage node 3) Migrate all instances and volumes to MZ 4) Maintenance hardware in SZ 5) SZ is becomes MZ, return 1) This spec is focused on 3), migrate instances and volumes from SZ to MZ. Problem description =================== It is hard to migrate all instances and volumes on SZ to MZ for a short period of time, with minimum downtime. Use Cases ---------- As an administrator, I want to migrate all instances and volumes on SZ to MZ automatically for a short period of time, with minimum downtime using Watcher continuous audit. Proposed change =============== Add or modify actions --------------------- As of now, migration action can migrate instances whose destination node is mandatory in the schema. Nova live migration API can deligate to nova scheduler to choose destination node. This spec proposes migration action can deligate to nova scheduler to choose destination compute node if migraration_type is live and destination node is empty. If cancel action plan called, action calls abort API. As of now there is no action to migrate volume. There are three migration API for volume. This spec proposes to add three actions in accordance with each migration API. Swap attached volume action *************************** This action is to migrate attached volume. This action can be done if instance is active, paused, or resized statues. Source volume and destination volume type are mandatory option. Since Nova swap volume API needs server, source volume and destination volume option, this action proceeds the following steps: - create an temporary user in the project created source volume - create destination volume by the temporary user - swap volume from source volume to destination volume (use Nova swap volume API) - delete source volume - delete the temporary user The action schema is:: schema = Schema({ 'resource_id': str, # volume id, 'destination_type': str, # destination volume type }) Migrate detached volume to the same volume type action ****************************************************** This action is to migrate detached volume to the same volume type. This action can be done if volume is detached, has no snapshots. Source volume and destination storage hostname are mandatory option. This action simply calls Cinder migration API. The action schema is:: schema = Schema({ 'resource_id': str, # volume id, 'destination_host': str, # destination host }) Migrate detached volume to the different volume type action *********************************************************** This action is to migrate detached volume to the different volume type. This action can be done if volume is detached, has no snapshots. source volume and destination volume type are mandatory option. This action simply calls Cinder retype API. The action schema is:: schema = Schema({ 'resource_id': str, # volume id, 'destination_type': str, # destination volume type }) Add zone migration goal ----------------------- This spec adds zone migration goal. The efficacy indicators of the goal is these items: - The number of active instances on SZ - The number of non-active instances on SZ - The number of attached volumes on SZ - The number of detached volumes on SZ - The number of migrated active instances on MZ - The number of migrated non-active instances on MZ - The number of migrated attached volumes on MZ - The number of migrated detached volumes on MZ - Zone migration Running time - End time of instances(remaining time) - End time of volumes(remaining time) End time = (biggest number of cycle in pre migration + biggest one under migration) * audit interval. Number of cycle is size / speed / audit interval. If target is instance, size is memory. If target is volume, size is volume size. Speed is mean execution time of the action for each aggregate or volume type. Modify compute cluster data model --------------------------------- As of now, compute cluster data model does not have status and aggregate information. This spec adds those information. Add zone migration strategy --------------------------- Display name is zone_migration. Goal is zone_migration goal. The zone migration strategy requires the following metrics. ==================================== ============ ======= ======= metric service name plugins comment ==================================== ============ ======= ======= ``hardware.network.incoming.bytes`` ceilometer_ SNMP_ none ``hardware.network.outgoing.bytes`` ceilometer_ SNMP_ none ==================================== ============ ======= ======= .. _ceilometer: http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide/telemetry-measurements.html#openstack-compute .. _SNMP: http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide/telemetry-measurements.html Strategy parameters are: ==================== ====== ===================== ============================ parameter type default Value description ==================== ====== ===================== ============================ ``instance`` array none Dicts where keys are src_hostname/src_aggregate and dst_hostname ``volume`` object none Dict where keys are src_hostname, dst_hostname, src_volume_type, dst_volume_type ``unavailable_time`` object none Dict specify audit suspend time where keys are start_time, end_time. ``multiplicity`` object |multiplicity| Dict specify action multiplicity where keys are total and per_host. ``threshould`` object |threshould| Threshould for metrics. Unit is byte/s. ``priority`` object none Dicts specify priority where keys are type and value. value of type is tenant, compute_host, storage_host, compute or storage. value of value is list, vary depend on type. ``exclusion`` object none Dicts where keys are type and value. value of type is tenant, compute_host, storage_host, instance or volume. value of value is list, vary depend on type. ``interval`` number 30 Choosing migration targets period(seconds) ``set_attached`` object false If true, migrate volume and instance attached together. If false, migrate instance after migrating all volumes ==================== ====== ===================== ============================ .. |threshold| replace:: {"type": "network", "value": {"compute_node": [100, 100], "storage_node": [500, 500]} .. |multiplicity| replace:: {"total": 1, "per_host": 1} This strategy choose volumes and instances on SZ to migrate according to priority and exclusion input parameters. Action multiplicity is decided from multiplicity input parameters and metrics. Add parallel workflow engine ---------------------------- This spec propose paralel workflow engine. This engine simply run actions in parallel. In addition to that, This engine expand/reduce cinder quota before/after running swap attached volume action. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- * Swap attached volume action creates temporary user, this is security risk. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: <nakamura-h> Other contributors: <adi-sky17> Work Items ---------- * Add or modify actions * Add zone migration goal * Add zone migration strategy * Add parallel workflow engine * Modify compute data model Dependencies ============ * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/watcher/+spec/cancel-action-plan * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/watcher/+spec/multiple-global-efficacy-indicator * https://blueprints.launchpad.net/watcher/+spec/cinder-model-integration Testing ======= Unit tests and tempest test will be added. Documentation Impact ==================== Strategy documentation will be added. References ========== None History ======= None

commit_message:
Move methods related to metering_label

The moved methods are used at test_metering_extensions only, so the
base module is not a good place to keep such methods. This patch moves
them into test_metering_extensions for keeping the base method simple.

Change-Id: I84c36cc3597b53953b4fb9fc7c42932682d44795
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/72/462772/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: @classmethod def create_metering_label(cls, name, description): """Wrapper utility that returns a test metering label.""" body = cls.admin_metering_labels_client.create_metering_label( description=description, name=name) metering_label = body['metering_label'] cls.metering_labels.append(metering_label) return metering_label @classmethod def create_metering_label_rule(cls, remote_ip_prefix, direction, metering_label_id): """Wrapper utility that returns a test metering label rule.""" client = cls.admin_metering_label_rules_client body = client.create_metering_label_rule( remote_ip_prefix=remote_ip_prefix, direction=direction, metering_label_id=metering_label_id) metering_label_rule = body['metering_label_rule'] cls.metering_label_rules.append(metering_label_rule) return metering_label_rule

commit_message:
Switch BaseAdminNetworkTest on test_routers_dvr

test_routers_dvr doesn't use BaseRouterTest specific methods at all,
so it is not necessary to inherit from BaseRouterTest. This patch
removes such unnecessary dependency for simple inheritance.

Change-Id: Ic9d741f64128e4532c2206a57954c7d1958bacef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/78/462778/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
